title: Colouring of strings sometimes wrong
desc: - using integration build I20021114 - this is an intermittent problem and I haven't yet come up with a  reproducible test case (gotta love these) - am using default preferences (so Strings appear in bright blue and  cntl+hover appears as bright blue and underlined)  I was cutting and pasting a number of lines into a class file.  Each line was  of the form: System.out.println("text with method or variable name");  Occassionally, when I pasted a line, the text in quotes would appear in black  instead of blue.  Scrolling this code off the screen and back on again would  not change the colour of the text.  Closing the class file and reopening it  would cause the text to be in bright blue.  Occassionally, something next to  the text would be in blue (don't remember if it was underlined as well) and  would remain blue if it was scrolled off the screen and back on.  Hints (don't know if this helps): - I was trying out cntl+hover at the same time  - I find if I am cutting and pasting a lot, I tend to select some text, do  cntl-C, lift my finger off the C but leave the cntl down, move to another spot  with the mouse, press V (so I get cntl V because I still have the cntl down)  to paste the text - i.e. I ride heavy on the cntl key (may need to get my  brakes replaced - or is that breaks?)

title: Internal method changes will break RetargetToolbarAction subclass
desc: RetargetToolbarAction is subclassing RetargetAction which states in its class  docs that it is not to be extended by clients.  I need to rename a method in the RetargetAction class. I will keep the old  method around for a couple of integration build so you can update this class.  On another note, is there anything the workbench can provide that would avoid  the need for this subclass?

title: [syntax highlighting] Out of the box semantic coloring settings
desc: When enabling semantic coloring the current default settings result in a too  colorful appearance.  1) we don't have to leverage all color settings out of the box and should only  use a reasonable subset of the settings. These settings need to look appealing. 2) need to decide on the colors for the subset  To simplify item 1) there should be a way to disable the coloring of an item.  Suggest to add a checkbox on the left of the color item. Having the checkbox  unchecked means use the default color.

title: "Hovers" preferences hard to use
desc: The "Hovers" tab in the Java editor preference page is difficult to use - in order to bring up the drop-down list to change the selection, you need to type a key, and it's not at all clear what key to press. The drop-downs for compiler preferences etc seem to be working fine, so I don't know why the hover ones aren't. (I confess I haven't looked at the code yet.)  I'm using M3.  Jon

title: Code assist light bulbs not removed from vertical bar after fix
desc: This doesn't happen all the time and no log is generated.  1)make sure the preference for marking non NLSed strings as warnings is set. 2)create a string somewhere in the code. 3)select the code assist light bulb and choose 'mark as non-externalisable' 4)save  Notice that neither the code assist light bulb in the left hand vertical bar  nor the warning marking in the right hand vertical bar have disapear. The  warning squillies have.  5) click on the light bulb again.  Notice the message now says 'no corrections available'.  I'm still looking for an exact way to reproduce this case as it seems to  happen in some editors and not others.  >20021115. JRT.

title: [formatting] Javadoc incorrect one line transformation
desc: When I have:  /** The particular AIS ID this processor listens for. */  That I want to turn into:  /**   * The particular AIS ID this processor listens for.   */  I type ENTER <HERE>:  /**<HERE> The particular AIS ID this processor listens for. */  I get:  	/** 	 *  	 */ The particular AIS ID this processor listens for. */  That's not right!

title: [smart editing] Smart indent - unexpected behavior
desc: Build 20021115.  I have a class defined as follows.  If I line-select the method run, copy and  paste it, the method is indented another level (vs. maintaining the level that  all the other methods are on).  This is undesirable behavior.  public class ObjectAction1Delegate 	extends ActionDelegate 	implements IObjectActionDelegate, IMenuCreator {  	public void run(IAction action) { 	} 	public void dispose() { 	} 	public Menu getMenu(Menu m) { 		return null; 	} 	public Menu getMenu(Control c) { 		return null; 	} }

title: Deleteing line using Ctrl+E shouldn't cut
desc: I find it rather annoying having put something into the clipboard and then  pressing Ctrl+E to tidy up what is left behind after I have cut a certain piece  of text and to my amazement the text I originally cut has been replaced with  the blank lines that I wanted to remove. I belive that the cutting of the text  into the clip board should be made optional or removed all together.

title: highlighting what to overwrite doesn't always work
desc: public class Test {    public Test()    {       Math.abs(2);    } } place the cursor just after the a in the abs function above and bring up the  auto complete pop up (Ctrl+Space). pressing Ctrl highlights what is going to be  deleted. If however the cursor was placed at the start of the abs function call  that highlighting will not occur.

title: Autocomplete for inner interfaces disapears
desc: public class Test {    private interface hello{}        public Test()    {       Test.h    } } place the cursor just after Test.h and press Ctrl+Space (the auto complete pop  up appears). as soon as you type "e" the popup disapears.

title: Using auto-complete in JavaDoc does not use fully qualified class name (in member JavaDoc comments)
desc: When inserting a class name into a JavaDoc comment, the fully qualified class name is not always included. If the class has been imported from another package using an import statement, then the unqualified name is inserted.  If you type:  import java.util.Vector; /**  * @see Vec  */   and then use the code-completion to select 'Vector' it comes up with  import java.util.Vector; /**  * @see Vector  */   instead of the required  import java.util.Vector; /**  * @see java.lang.Vector  */   This also happens in {@link } tags as well as after @see tags.  It's quite possible that other code-generation routine (i.e. guessing parameters, exception names etc.) are inserted as unqualified class names instead of the fully qualified ones as well, but that's probably the subject of another bug ...

title: javadoc wraps on period character even when there's no space
desc: Build: 2.1 M3 The automatic line breaking in javadoc comments will break up words separated by the period character, even if there is no whitespace. For example, the comment: /** * This is a javadoc comment that makes a reference to java.lang. * String */ It has broken up java.lang.String across lines. I think it should keep words together unless separated by whitespace.

title: Code assist type filters
desc: It would improve my productivity if I could apply filters to the list of things code assist suggests.  This way I could exclude all awt/swing types when I am working on an SWT project.  Or, if my team's coding convensions disallowed use of the java.util types, I wouldn't have to worry that a class snuck in because of code assist.  This feature would require: 1. A new preference page (a global one, and one per-project) where the user specifies which patterns to be filtered.  This could easily be copied from the debug step filtering preference page. 2. Filtering mechanism on top of or inside code assist itself.  Optional: Item in the code assist list that would show all the filtered types.  For example, with the filters the list would look like:  org.blah.Foo com.example.Bar <show filtered items>  If the user selected "<show filtered items>" the list would expand to include the filtered types.

title: Double quotes - your tab *will* go where I want it to
desc: With "Prefs -> Java|Editor|Behaviour|Automatically close strings" set to true, do the following: Hit double quote once. You get "", with the cursor between the quotes. Type foo. You get "foo", with the insert cursor after the last 'o'. The foo is underlined in green. You now have two possibilties. They are: 1) Hit tab. The green line vanishes, and the insert cursor moves to be after the closing quote. This is fine 2) Use the cusor keys or click with the mouse to move the insert cusror to somewhere else in the file. If we type anything except a tab, the green line vanishes, and we get the appropriate character in the place we expect. If we hit a tab, the cursor magically flies back to our closing quote, and a tab gets inserted. This is bad. What I think *should* happen is that the green line and thus the tab-based tab- based behaviour should stop if the user moves the cursor outside the quotes.

title: Java editor types text backwords
desc: Using build 200211191210, I got into a state where the Java editor for a  particular class was very slow and everthing I typed was backwards. I could not  close the editor in question due to bug 26953 but I could close other java  editors and typing in other editors worked fine as well. I had to restart  Eclipse to fix the problem.

title: Outline pop-up: flicker when filtering
desc: 1) open the outline pop-up (ctrl-O) 2) type in a letter ->observe that you can watch how the tree items are removed and then added  again.  Use of setRedraw(false/true) during filtering should avoid this flickering

title: [typing] Smart string wrapping
desc: Using1119, I noticed something quite annoying. Consider the following code:  String s = "";  If you copy some code like: class A { // comment }   And then you paste it between the double-quotes, you will end up with: 	String s = "public class A { // comment" + 		"}"; The problem is that this code is not equivalent. I should have a line break at the end of the first line. Otherwise the code contained in my string s doesn't even compile. So the feature is nice, but cannot be used till a line break is added at the end of each part of the string concatenation.   So in the above example, I would expect: 	String s = "public class A { // comment\n" + 		"}"; or  	String s = "public class A { // comment\r\n" + 		"}"; or 	String s = "public class A { // comment\r" + 		"}"; The line break could be chosen according to the line breaks in the current file or the platform line delimiter.

title: Open Structure/Show Outline doesn't work inside a string literal
desc: When the cursor is positioned inside a string literal, the Structure viewer doesn't pop up. This goes for both the Open Structure (Ctrl-F3) and the Show Outline (Ctrl-O).

title: Editor colors
desc: Some times, the colors of the source code in the editor gets mixed. see attachment.

title: Writing text in Javadoc comment is backwards
desc: When writing a Javadoc comment (both on class, method and attribute), the text is inserted backwards (when inserting a character, the cursor is moved one position to the left, i.e. to the left of the inserted character). This behaviour is reproducible on any .java file.  I'm using the "200211230010" nightly build.

title: No support for Show Outline in class files with source attachment
desc: 1) Open a class file from rt.jar in the editor.  2) press ctrl-o nothing happens would have expected that the outline shows up as well.  As a user I don't really know whether am in a source file or a class file and  expect that quick navigation works in both modes. In particular this means that  for class files I have to use the outline view (which I had hidden).

title: something leaks StyleRanges and Lines
desc: 180K of StyleReanges and 47K of Lines after: -open editor -close editor  seems like StyleRange objects are never freed

title: Problem indicators not updated
desc: 20021126 smoke 1. Junit in workspace 2. Open 'SimpleTest.java', select 'Test' in 'suite()'. 3. from the context menu activate 'refactor->rename', enter name 'Test2' 4. after the refactoring, the editor contains two problem indicators on 'Test2'  and on 'SimpleTest'. Both of them are wrong, the file is fine. 5. Typing a space in the editor lets the indication go away.

title: Outline view won't sync editor unless "Go Into Top Level Type" is selected
desc: Since M3 was released I have to have "Go Into Top Level Type" selected or I cannot navigate using the outline view.  If I move around in the editor window the outline highlight syncs fine, but selecting fields or methods (or anything) in the outline view does not cause the editor to sync.  If I select the "Go Into Top Level Type" option w/in the outline view then the editor is syncs fine.

title: Severe editor corruption during cut & paste
desc: Build I20021127 (also noticed in I20021119)  I am experiencing a bug that causes severe corruption of the editors.  Once in the corrupt state, the editor presentation is garbled and not correctly drawn.  Trying to save or close the editor has no effect (apart from more stack traces).  A shutdown and restart is required to make the problem go away, and errors occur on both shutdown and restart.  I will try to come up with a test case.  I will attach the log file.

title: single cut/undo allocates 2Mb of garbage of char[]
desc: 20021127 in a large file (SWT.java) i cut something from within a comment and undid the action it allocated a lot of objects - including 3Mb of char[] attached is allocation backtrace  seems like calling codeselect allocates a lot of stuff - maybe unnecessarily or  maybe we could avoid calling it on every keystroke

title: Cursor in wrong position after paste
desc: Build 20021127  1) Start with the following JCU:  public class Testing { 	private int foo; 	int another; }  2) Copy the word "private" to the clipboard. 3) Position the cursor before the letter "i" on the "int another;" line. 4) Hit paste.  -> After the paste, the cursor is positioned after the letter "o" of the word "another".

title: Smart Paste indents incorrectly
desc: Build 20021127    Start with the following code:   public class Test {       public static void main(String[] args) {           System.out.println("Test 1");           System.out.println("Test 2");       }   }     Select the second line with System.out, hit Ctrl+X to cut, hit Ctrl+V to paste  and you end up with:    public class Test {       public static void main(String[] args) {           System.out.println("Test 1");               System.out.println("Test 2");       }   }   The second line is indented incorrectly. Smart paste should substract the  original indentation.

title: HTML2TextReader allocates large numbers of String objects very rapidly
desc: HTML2TextReader.processPreformattedText seems to create a new String object for  every single character ever displayed in a javadoc hover  this adds up to hundreds of kilobytes after just a couple of seconds. StringBuffer.insert for which the Strings are used accepts chars as well -  maybe that method could be used intead

title: Cut and Paste not working properly
desc: In builds I20021203 and N20021204 a strange effect occurs when copying and  pasting source code in the Java Browsing view.  When you try and copy source  from a read only (attached source) class view (e.g. JList) into your own  source view (not read only - and not attached source) the cut command is  ignored.  This didn't use to happen with M3.  (This is easily monitored if you watch cut and paste activity in the MS Office  Clipboard - copying from your own code appears in the clipboard, but copying  from read only attached source doesn't.  Switching off the clipboard doesn't  help, so it isn't the clipboard causing the problem)

title: show tooltip description (F2) is disabled on read-only files
desc: If a read-only java file is opened in editor F2 on a method won't work. The  only way to make it work is to clear read only flag and reopen the file.

title: Cannot copy content of classfile editor
desc: 20021204  Open a class file with source attachment  try select all: does not work copy to clipboard: does not work   see als bug 27736

title: Javadoc Formater corrupts Javadoc
desc:
The new "online" Javadoc formater is great, but it should be more intelligent. For example: If next line starts with "

" the formater shouldn't unwrap it istead it should keep the line as a new line. The same should be applied for the "

"  tag and the content between the "
" tags should be completely ignored and  not formated.  Also statements between "" tags shouldn't be wrapped or divided.  (example: "org.eclipse.somwhat" becomes "org. eclips.  somewhat"

title: editor tab enhancement
desc: the editor tabs should have a "close all other tab" pop-up menue when clicked with the right mouse button (like in mozilla).  i usually navigate through a couple of files to understand what's going on and which file i have to change. once i find the correct file i want to get rid of all the other open editors at once.

title: Ctrl+C shows an error message
desc: In a read-only file if you highlight some text and press Ctrl+C to copy that  text an error dialog pops up complaining that the file is read-only. Surely  copying some text does not require a writable file! Integration Build: 200212041234

title: Template preferences don't get exported
desc: Input from Code Camp Stuttgart (Build 20021204)  When exporting all preferences the templates don't get included. They have to be exported manually via the Templates preference page.

title: Refresh from local can trigger a full build without having a progress monitor
desc: Build I20021204 + 1204 export  I aborted Eclipse on a big self hosting workspace (no correct saving of the  state). Restarting the workspace worked fine but when I opened the first  compilation unit a full build kicked in as a side effect of  Resource.refreshLocal call from  CompilationUnitDocumentProvider.createElementInfo.   No progress monitor is shown in the case. No chance to cancel the full build.

title: JavaEditor leaks OS resources (Colors and Cursors)
desc: see bug 27114 for the trigger. calling fColor.dipose() fCursor.dipose() should be always be attempted - currently it does not happen if JavaEditor.MouseClickListener.uninstall returns before the end of the method

title: smartPaste should not call JavaCore.getOptions for each inserted line
desc: test case: pasting 5000 lines into a cu smart paste on 60% of time is spent in checking is spaces or tabs should be used - seems like  it's asked for 1 per line  asking 1 per paste would suffice

title: Editing javadoc comments doesn't provide scrolling if cursor goes behind visible area of editor
desc: I'm typing JavaDoc description and cursor disappears on right of the editor  view. I should manually scroll it to see, what am typing. Print/line split margins are set to 120 and it's behind visible area on my  screen if scroll is set to 0.

title: Smart edit too smart when inserting brackets
desc: Build 20021012  - given the following method body:    foo();  - now insert a new line before foo and start typing    if (expression) {  observe: smart edit inserts a closing bracket after method invocation foo();  IMO in 99% of the cases this is not what the user wants when typing the full if  statement. The generated code should look like:  if (expression) { } foo();

title: 16% of opening java file spent in expanding list of Ranges
desc: more than 16% of time needed to open an editor is spent in expandCapacity on  the list of StyleRanges in TextPresentation

title: 14% of java file opening time spent in TextViewer .applyTextPresentation
desc: most of which is spent in enlarging the size of 1 arraylist (this is strange - how does this relate to bug 28176 ?)

title: smart home/end cannot be disabled and is not standard behavior
desc: -cannot disable smart home/end even if unchecked from the prefs.  -the first home hit should not bring to left edge but the first non-blank char, the second hit should, then alternate  -the end hit should not bring anywhere else than the absolute end of line, like ALL know editors do. There is no point to ignore blank char that should be removed anyway.  -should be broken down 2 option: smart home, smart end.

title: [templates] Variable resolver resolves to array of specified type
desc: I20070821-0800  Given: package test; public class E01 { 	public void foo() { 		String[] strings= null; 		String string= null; 		out| 	} 	public void out(String s) {} }  1. Add template 'out' to java context with pattern: out(${name:var(java.lang.String)}); 2. Replace '|' with caret 3. Ctrl-Space, Ctrl-Space 4. Enter Is: - string - strings is proposed Should: - string is proposed  'var' template variable doc is: 'Evaluates to a field, local variable or parameter visible in the current scope that is a subtype of the given type.'  String[] is not a subtype of String.

title: Copy/paste or delete in block/javadoc comments doesn't work as expected
desc: Using 1210, with ALL smart settings disabled. It is not possible to do a copy/paster or a delete in block comments at some locations. 1) Create a class with this contents. /*  * SELECT THIS LINE  */ public class A {  } 2) Select the whole line containing SELECT THIS LINE. 3) Do Ctrl + C (copy) 4) Go at the beginning of the next line. 5) Paste. I end up with: /*  * SELECT THIS LINE  * SELECT THIS LINE  * */ instead of: /*  * SELECT THIS LINE  * SELECT THIS LINE  */ This is the same bug for pasting anywhere in the comment.  Now the deletion problem.  1) Take this source: /*  *   *   * / public class A {  } 2) Put the cursor on the space between the last '*' and '/'. 3) Press delete. You end up with: /*  *   * / instead of: /*  *  *  */ So you can never close this block comment.  Version 2 of the same problem: /*  * TEXT  * |<cursor>  */  Try to delete the space where the cursor is. It won't simply erase the space.  I like when a text editor stays a text editor. If I disable all smart behaviors, I like them to stay disabled.

title: JavaEditorPreferencePage and JavaColorManager leak Colors

title: [info views] Regressions from bug 393143
desc: This bug is the parent of bug 403000, bug 403004, bug 403016 and bug 403023.

title: [misc] Quick outline doesn't go away when Eclipse looses focus
desc: I20021216 (M4)  - open quick outline (Ctrl+0) - switch to another application (e.g. Windows Explorer) observe: the outline view stays on top of the other application.

title: Unnecessary bracket when using code assist to create annonymous inner classes
desc: IBuild 20021216 (M4)  Create the following CU  import java.util.Arrays; import java.util.Comparator;  public class A { 	public void foo(int i) { 		String strings[] = null; 		Arrays.sort(strings, new Comparator) 	} }  - now type ( after Comparator - press Ctrl+Space to open code assist observe: an annonymous inner class is inserted. The code assist proposal also  inserts a closing bracket, which results in a compile error

title: Editor input icon should differentiate files that are not on the build class path
desc: The package explorer (using the Java Label Provider) shows CUs that are not on  the build class path using a grey icon. The editor should use the same icon  when the corresponding CU is not on the build class path. JavaCore provides an  API method for the isOnClassPath check.

title: Pesimistic VC: Content Assist dissabled, Quick Fix still available
desc: 20021216  Looks like the behaviour is not consistent: On checked-in files content assist  is disabled, but quick fix can still be invoked (and does a check-out to find  out that no corrections are available)

title: Quickfix icon hides the error icon in editor left ruler [quick fix]
desc: Build 20021216  In presence of problems, one cannot see an error icon in the left ruler, since  it get overlapped completely with the quickfix icon.  The only error indication is the underlining in the code itself.

title: Templates should be auto-formatted
desc: build I20021217  - new workspace - new Java project - new class Test - place cursor at the start of the blank line in the body of the class - type: main<Ctrl+Space> and select the main method template - it is inserted at the start of the blank line - select the whole method and cut it - paste it back in the same place - it is now indented  Need to determine whether auto-formatting makes sense for all templates, or  just certain kinds like this one.

title: Adding break point updates hierarchy view
desc: Eclipse 20021218  Display the hierarchy view for an open file.  Now add a breakpoint to a method  of that file.  Note the flash in the hierarchy view.

title: [typing] Balance should not remove parenthesis
desc: In M4, if the balance options are on and you type a left parenthesis a right parenthesis is inserted. Well and good. But if you position the cursor to the right of the right parenthesis and backspace, both the right and left parenthesis are deleted. This is not good. For example, suppose you have:    super("description");  And you decide to wrap the string in a method call, e.g., by typing    super(Local.getString("description");  As soon as you type the ( after getString, a second parenthesis is inserted, giving:    super(Local.getString()"description");  But the right parenthesis isn't where it should be, so you try to delete it. But as soon as you delete the right parens, the left is removed also, giving:    super(Local.getString"description");  The only way to get parens around the string is to cut and paste the string into the parenthesis. This is too hard. Balancing should not interfere with user editing. Same comment applies to brackets, braces, etc.

title: [typing] Automatically close braces working incorrectly
desc: Produces code like  addMouseListener(new MouseListener() {) }  when you enter the opening brace at the position marked with X below  addMouseListener(new MouseListener() X)  Eclipse 2.1 M4, J2SDK 1.4.1_01

title: Shift+Tab indents instead of unindenting
desc: Press Home to go to the beginning of text on a line (NOT column 0).  Shift+Tab indents instead of unindenting.

title: [templates] Template should add imports if needed
desc: From bug 27377.  ..... Similary whenever a template is used and it uses types which are not  imported it would be nice to be able to specify in the template which imports  are required or to just run the "organise imports" function after every  template is used.

title: Show Outline fails on read-only files
desc: [M4]  For some reasoning, trying to use Show Outline on a read-only file results in the error message:  Problems editing file  The file cannot be edited. Reason: File [...] is read-only.  Why should showing the outline of a class require it to be edited?

title: I-beam cursor sometimes lost
desc: [M4 - haven't seen this problem previously]  [Note that this could well be a platform editor problem - I don't often edit non-Java files, so it's hard to say]  When editing a Java file, fairly frequently the I-beam turns into a normal pointer cursor, and stays that way for that file. Other files are okay, but switching between files, the "broken" file stays broken until it is closed and reopened.

title: Preferences>Java>Editor>Hovers is not accessible
desc: You cannot change a value with the keyboard only.  Similarly the userinterface is currently not intuitive (Default Hover shows up  in both columns, "best match" isn't clear to the user)

title: ctrl+O outline not usable on GTK
desc: 20030117 the ctrl+O outline is not usable on gtk because it goes away after you press any key

title: No overview ruler in class file editor
desc: Now that we support to show general markers (like search results) in the  overview ruler, we should also provide an overview ruler in the class file  editor.   Support for wiggley would be nice as well.

title: [M4] Javadoc line wrap word break detection
desc: Javadoc line wrap breaks words after a minus/hyphen, e.g., well-known into  well- known. This is inappropriate for HTML, because a browser will not  eliminate the added space when the line is re-flowed. From that time on, it  will be displayed as "word- wrap".  In fact, even the same line wrap code does not rejoin the word, so you have  the situation that inserting a character and backspacing in lines with  hyphenated words will insert an extra space character.

title: [navigation] ctrl+O outline way too large to use
desc: 20030107 the shell that comes up after pressing ctrl+O covers the whole screen height on GTK, which makes it not usable

title: [hovering] JavaDoc Hover should interprete &-tags
desc: The javadoc hover should recognize and interprete HTML &...; tags so that  things like the following (german) javadoc is shown correctly:  /** Eine schöne Methode */ void foo(void) { }  The JavaDoc hover of "foo" should display "Eine schöne Methode" instead  of "Eine schöne Methode".

title: open structure popup doesn't work on readonly files
desc: whenever I CTRL-F3 (Open Structure) on a readonly java file, I get an error message "This file cannot be edited. ..."

title: I can input a "tab" into a Java file.
desc: I have already made "Insert space for tabs" checked. But I can still input  a "tab" into Javadoc, and there's no way to change these tabs to space. I think it's feasible that making that option valid for editing a Javadoc.

title: Java editer should have a command to match brackets
desc: Java editor should have a command to match brackets. It shouldn’t be that difficult since there is a setting to highlight matching  brackets

title: Quick Fix 'rename' removes character after template region.
desc: - invoke Quick Fix 'rename' on a variable - move cursor to the end of the template region, like:     int test|= 123;     test= 321;   (where '|' indicates the cursor, not a real character) - press delete, results in:     int test| 123;     test 321;        ^^The '=' is gone.

title: [syntax highlighting] Color code elements by scope
desc: In Java you can declare local variables just about anywhere in the code. That  makes it difficult to, at a glance, see if a variable is local, a parameter or  a instance or static field of the class. Naming conventions are often imposed  to remedy this. However, different shops have a habit adopting different  naming conventions, and you are increasingly likely to use toolkits in source  form from a number of different origins.   It would be helpful if it was possible to assign different colors to  identifiers by their scope, so that e.g. fields and local variables would  stand out as different in the editor.

title: Annotations underlining disappear
desc: After some time of editing it seems that since integration build I20030115  annotations sometimes stop working. I.E. the underlining of errors in the  editor disappears, although the lightbulbs do still appear in the margin on the  left. After stopping and restarting Eclipse the underlines are back. I cannot  reliably reproduce this bug but I thought I would report it anyway. I will  attatch my preferences file in case it helps. If I can reproduce it reliably I  will add to the bug report!

title: No overview ruler for class files
desc: build 2003-01-22, linux-gtk, ibm jre 1.3.1  There doesn't seem to be an overview ruler for class files but there does for Java files. I would expect it to appear for both since I display items like search results in this ruler.

title: Enter at start of javadoc line messes up comment
desc: build I20030115  In a method like: 	/** 	 * First line. 	 * Second line. 	 */ 	void m() {}  Move the cursor to the start of the "Second line" in the Javadoc (column 1). Hit Enter, as if you want to enter a new line. You get the following, with | indicating the current cursor position.  	/** 	 * First line.  	 * |	 * Second line. 	 */  It should give:  	/** 	 * First line. 	 * | 	 * Second line. 	 */

title: Templates - should mention that $ need to be doubled
desc: Build 20030122  When adding a new template "//$NON-NLS-1$", the template dialog complains about  a variable name. It should also suggest to double dollar signs.

title: Templates - should include a "nls" template by default
desc: Build 20030122  I find useful to define a template for tagging string literal as non-nls. I  believe it could be provided by default.  Name:         nls Description:  Non-NLS tag Pattern:      //$$NON-NLS-1$$

title: [hovering] Javadoc hover on @see tags in overriden/implemented methods incorrectly show class javadoc
desc: Implement/override a method from superclass/interface. Eclipse inserts @see- tag of the form:  @see SuperClass#method(ArgumentType)  If you hover above SuperClass it will show you the javadocs of SuperClass.  There is no way to show the javadoc of SuperClass.method(ArgumentType).

title: Adapt to platform text tests moving to JUnit 4
desc: Adjustment for tests extending platform.text ones.

title: Cannot open classfile which is in output folder
desc: Build 20030122  When selecting a classfile which is inside an output folder, I get a dialog  reading "The classfile is not on the classpath".  I think it should instead not use a Java editor, and forward the opening to  another editor (I could imagine one rendering generated classfiles).  At worse, it would use the default text editor. Not opening a file on user  request feels a limitation.

title: Print margin is broken
desc: In the newest build, the print margin does not seem to work correctly. When ever I open a new Java-class by (for example) double-clicking it, the print margin shows in a wrong position. In my case the Preferences->Java->editor says 80, but the margin is drawed approximately to 60:th column. The problem concernes only new windows; I can work around the problem by setting the option "recycle windows" and for every window, open the Preferences->Java->editor, unselect the option "Show pring margin", click apply, select the option again and finally click the apply button again.

title: New 'for' template to include with default installation [templates]
desc: I find this template useful. It seems generic enough that it could be included with the default set of templates.  Template name: for Template description: iterator over a range of integers Template body:  for (int ${index} = ${start}; ${index} < ${end}; ${index}++) {     ${cursor} }

title: BIDI: The Keyboard layer changes with keystrokes
desc: Tested on WinXp Arabic locale set as default, build eclipse-SDK-I20030128- win32.zip. - Make a new Project - Make a new Java file. - In the main method write System.out.println(") Then the editor will insert  the second " and the String will be System.out.println(""). Between the double  cotes change the keyboard layer to Arabic after insertion of the first  character the keyboard layer changes back to English automatically.  NB: This behavior is not there when I try to write Arabic anywhere else in the  editor.

title: Ctrl+O prompter gets placed off screen
desc: build I20030115  - maximize the eclipse window - open a large CU - zoom it - position the caret in the first line of text - scroll it up 20 lines or so - Ctrl+O - the outline prompter is cut off by the top of the screen  There are similar issues when the caret is scrolled off the bottom, but it  seems to check for the bottom of the screen.  Could just position the prompter below the first visible line if the caret is  not visible.

title: [content assist][preferences] Link static imports pref should have link to 'Favorites' pref page
desc: 3.4  'Use static imports' should have a link to the 'Favorites' page

title: Java editor swallows my pressed key
desc: 20030203  1. use code assist to choose a method with arguments 2. type the argument name. Note that the editor is in template mode 3. use the mouse to position the cursor after the closing bracket. 4. type a semicolon. Nothing happens.

title: Feature to disable markers in annotation bars
desc: I20030205  The editor preference page allows customization of where markers are rendered  in the editor. For some markers (especially search) I would like the ability to  exclude them in the annotation bar.

title: [smart editing] smart braces and comments
desc: M5 - type this:    int i= 1;    if (i == 2)       i= 3; - insert '{' after closing parenthesis Observe: a closing '}' is inserted after statement "i=3"  - remove both braces - add a line comment between if-statement and assigment    int i= 1;    if (i == 2)       // a comment       i= 3; - insert '{' after closing parenthesis Observe: a closing '}' is inserted before comment  It would be nice if existence of comment would not change behavior

title: [content assist] Auto-activation fails if '.' is pressed while content assist is active
desc: In the Java Code I wanna type 'System.out.println' I type in the following  Syste  hit CTRL+Space and a list appears. Since 'System' is the requested one, I type '.' which will be completed as 'System.'  BUT no further Code Assist is displayed.  1) The Code Assist should be displayed.  2) When type 'System.o' + CTRL+SPACE => Code assist with only one selection. In the Preferences->Editor->CodeAssist the option 'Insert single proposal automatical' is checked! => Why is not out automatically completed resp. Code Assist will be reopened again?  BTW: The options of the Code Assist are the default options, ie all are marked except 'Present proposal ...' and 'Fill argument names ...'

title: [preferences] Duplicate preferences for Text and Java Editor
desc: I20030206  There are duplicate preference options for Text and Java Editor. Would be nice if the Java Editor could inherit the settings from the Text Editor, so that I  only have to change them once.

title: [typing] Paste autoindents incorrectly in multi-line parameter lists
desc: I200302061700 eclipse linux-gtk  Paste autoindent works sufficiently that I'm surprised when it fails.  When I have an expression spread across multiple lines, especially in the form of a method call, paste autoindents one tab shy of correct.  Example. Starting with: 	assertEquals( 		expectedMessage.getToPSet(), 		db.item().getToParticipants(itemId) 	);  Trying to paste in a line, I end up with 	assertEquals( 	"to", 		expectedMessage.getToPSet(), 		db.item().getToParticipants(itemId) 	); rather than the desired 	assertEquals( 		"to", 		expectedMessage.getToPSet(), 		db.item().getToParticipants(itemId) 	);  This can actually be an irritation when I making a systematic change to a large number of calls, since without autoindent I could usually get my paste buffer to contain exactly the right number of tabs.  Now, even if I take the care to get the right number of tabs before cutting, autoindent "corrects" my desired value to give me something that I have to go back and fix up.

title: Apply doesn't  immediately update value
desc: In Preferences->Java->Editor->Appearance, the Matching brackets highlight color doesn't take immediate effect when pressing Apply like the other color settings in the list.

title: Current line highlighter can be cheated
desc: private HashMap fMethodMap = null; [remove space between '= null', choose format from context menu, move cursor  one line down with keyboard, tow lines should be highlighted]

title: shortcut to making a file writable
desc: Whenever you attempt to modify a read-only file a dialog pops up saying there  was a problem editing the file. It would be nice if on that dialog there was a  key that allowed you to change the attribute of that file to writable and then  perform the attempted operation.

title: Package explorer not synchronized to editor.
desc: It is no longer the case that the package explorer automatically synchronizes to the current text editor. There doesn't seem to be a preference to bring back this occasionally very handy behavior.  This wouldn't be a problem if it were possible to bind a keystroke to "Show In Package Explorer", but it doesn't seem to be possible. Every attempt to bind this action to a keystroke in the keystroke assignment pref pane results in... no response to the assigned keystroke. Alt-shift-s followed by return is one keystroke too many, IMHO, though it does work.

title: <CTRL><Space> for Codecompletion don't work in M5
desc: Hi,  like in the summary writen doesn't work the codecompletion in M5. In the preferences tab to set the key there is a conflict shown but not  explaint.   Yours Rüdiger

title: [misc] missing empty line after Javadoc text in case of @deprecated
desc: I20080805-0100 + plug-in export.  public class C { 	/** 	 * This is a test. 	 *  	 * @since 3.5 	 */ 	void f() { 	} 	/** 	 * This is a test. 	 *  	 * @since 3.5 	 * @deprecated as of 3.5 	 */ 	void f2() { 		 	} }  ==> hover for f is OK but for f2 the empty line is missing.

title: Read-only Java editor should indicate why it is read-only.
desc: During and after a debug session, the Eclipse GUI seems to be rather screwed up as far as the access to basic Java editing functions is concerned.  The debugger opens a view on my source code that  looks like a Java Editor window.  Only it doesn't behave that way at all.  But in that window, I cannot edit (change source). It will ignore any attempt to do so.  When I close down the debugger and change to the Java perspective, the behaviour persists.  Also, the "Outline" view should offer an alternative view to what I see in that Java editor.  It doesn't, the outline remains blank and empty.  Closing that broken Java editor and reopening the same .java - file heals the problem.  This is 2.1 M4, I'm running Eclipse itself under SUN JDK 1.4.1 and debug my application using SUN JRE 1.3.1, in case that matters.

title: Linked editing does not work in segmented mode
desc: Build I20030211  1. Open TestCase.java in Java editor 2. Switch to segmented mode 3. Select method runTest() 4. Select local variable 'runMethod' 5. Ctrl+1 6. Select 'local rename' 7. Start typing Observe: keystroke exits linked edit mode  Note: It was broken after I20030122

title: [navigation] Double-click in outline should activate editor
desc: - open a java file - select a method in its outline view - it scrolls to the right place - double-click on it - nothing happens  It would be better if it activated the editor. This is particularly helpful when keyboard navigating. I could hit CTRL+ALT+O to get to the Outline (or use the new CTRL+F7 view  switcher), select the item I want, then hit Enter, and it would jump me back to  the editor at the right place.   This would work very nicely if the outline was a fast view too.  If this is not a general outline problem, but should be handled by the Java  outline page, please bump up to JDT.  It would be good if we could have a fix for this by our mouse-free day on  Monday, Nov. 19th. Thanks.

title: smart brace insertion does not work for classes
desc: 20020306 + plugins from 0211 enter class Foo{  expected: class Foo{  ${cursor} }  but nothing is inserted it does work for methods

title: [misc] Double click should auto select comment
desc: Stable Build: 20020125  It should be possible to double click at the start or end of a long comment  (i.e.  /*  or */) and have it automatically select the entire comment.  Thanks.

title: Autoformatting of javadoc comments doesn't work properly
desc:
In 2.1 [20030129] Automatic formatting of javadoc comments is nice feature for writing javadocs. However, it is not working properly with 
 tags.   Very often piece of example code (or such) is wanted to be    provided within javadoc.      Autoformatting feature makes it next to impossible to write them,   since feature automatically completely messes up them.

title: Undo should undo auto-insertions
desc: build N20021209  While entering a method, I typed {. It entered the matching }. I hit Ctrl+Z. It only undid the {. Hitting Ctrl+Z again undid the }.  Ctrl+Z should always correspond to user actions.  In this case, I only did one  action (type {), and JDT did some work for free for me.  Undo should undo this  work as well as my typing.

title: Incorrect positions for warning annotations
desc: build I20030205 - In self-hosting workspace with org.eclipse.ui and friends in source, - open type / BasicNewProjectResourceWizard - the marker summary bar indicates two warnings in different places - the second one complains about the ref to the deprecated constant IWorkbenchPreferenceConstants.OPEN_PERSPECTIVE_PAGE - its range is correct, but there is no warning icon for it in the ruler - the first one is random -- it highlights the range indicated by [[...]] in the following, and has a warning icon: /** * Stores the configuration element for the wizard. Th[[e config element will be used * in performF]]inish to set the result perspective. */ public void setInitializationData(IConfigurationElement cfig, String propertyName, Object data) { configElement = cfig; }

title: [navigation] IllegalArgumentException closing editor
desc: build i0211 (1350), linux-gtk, redhat 8, ibm jre 1.3.1  I was closing my editors one at a time via ctrl-click and I got the following log file. Note that this might be obsolete since I believe that the "ctrl-click to close" behaviour is being removed for 2.1.  Will attach log file.

title: NPE when opening ClassFile Editor
desc: Build: I-20030326  I encountered the NPE below in JDT UI code when I was testing classpath  containers.  Steps to reproduce: 1. Fresh workspace. 2. Go to Plug-in Development->Java Build Path Control preference page, and  check the 'use classpath containers' checkbox. 3. Create a Hello, World plug-in project. 4. Go to Plug-in Development->Target Platform preference page.  Choose  the 'another compatible application' and browse for a WSADIE build.  Reload and  sselect all plugins.   Press OK. 5. In the package explorer view.  Expand the Hello, World project to see  the 'Required plug-in entries' container.  Expand it.  Now  expand 'resources.jar'.  Try to open any .class file in this jar, you will get  the NPE below. title: [hovering] hover for the editor error/warning indicator
desc: 20030211 it'd be nice to have a hover help for the top-right error indicator in the  editor  something like: "you have 1 error and 2 warnings in this file" it'd serve 2 purposes:  - explain to people what the thing means (when i don't know what something is,  i hover over it and expect some help)  - provide a lightweigth (i.e. task-list-less) way to count errors/warning

title: [hovering] parse javadoc information from javadoc files instead of source files
desc: Please,  parse javadoc information from javadoc files instead of source files.  Souce files are not always available and -anyway- javadoc documentation bundles should be all you need.

title: Scrollbar in Ctrl+O prompter jumps around a lot when many nested types
desc: build I20030211  - open Collections.class from java.util - Ctrl+O - type 'a' - backspace - the scrollbar goes wild - a couple of seconds later, you're back to the initial state

title: "for - iterate over a collection" template: incorrect tabs
desc: Build id: 200302131253  Create a new class, check the "public static void main(String[] args)" checkbox in the wizard.  Put the cursor after the method declaration, hit enter.  The cursor is now inside the method, on a blank line, tabbed to the right of the method declaration.  Now type "for", hit Ctrl-space, and select "for - iterate over a collation".  Notice that the inserted template is shifted to the left by one tab.

title: [misc] Backout workaround for bug 41583
desc: We added workarounds (see bug 41583, comment 35) which can now be removed.

title: truncated green template underscore line
desc: Build id: 200302131253  Create a new class, check the "public static void main(String[] args)" checkbox in the wizard. Put the cursor after the method declaration, hit enter.  The cursor is now inside the method, on a blank line, tabbed to the right of the method declaration.  Now type "for", hit Ctrl-space, and select "for - iterate over a collation".  Hit tab until the temporary variable inside the for loop is highlighted (it should be named "element").  Hit the right arrow button to move the cursor to the end of "element" and de-select "element".  Now hit the "delete" key.  Notice that the green template line shortens by one character.

title: [templates] ${enclosing_*} doesn't work  in M4
desc: All those enclosing_* variables that can be used in templates are no longer replaced with the values but treated as ordinary variables

title: persistant green template underscore line
desc: Build id: 200302131253  Create a new class, check the "public static void main(String[] args)" checkbox in the wizard. Put the cursor after the method declaration, hit enter.  The cursor is now inside the method, on a blank line, tabbed to the right of the method declaration.  Now type "for", hit Ctrl-space, and select "for - iterate over a collation".  Hit tab until the temporary variable inside the for loop is highlighted (it should be named "element").  Hit the right arrow button to move the cursor to the end of "element" and de-select "element".  Now hit the "delete" key.  Now hit the down arrow, the green template line remains.

title: [misc] Java Editor on big files frozen for seconds after post selection
desc: I20031029 (or earlier)  1. Open JavaEditor.java in the Java editor 2. scroll down to half of file 3. type some text ==> editor blocks for some time  The time increases with the number of views that are linked to the editor, e.g. Java Browsing perspective is a good test case.  There are several areas where the time can be spent: - in the editor - view updating - in J Core (AST, codeResolve, reconciling the CU) - delta processing of views

title: Error when opening editor on class file not hosted in a Java project
desc: I20030214  - create Simple project - create a file A.class - open it  observe: you get an error saying that Simple doesn't exist.

title: [misc] Editing error - loss of data
desc: I just downloaded I20031105 and installed it into a clean directory as a  replacement for I20030917. I run on a dual 933Mhz processor under Sun Java  1.4.2_02 with 1GB of physical memory. I access my workspace via -data.  I brought up Eclipse and after 10 min. of editing I had the file  ICliCommand.java in the state that I attach to ths report. At this point,  starting with the cursor at the end of line 128, I typed the following three  lines.  <newline>     void changeTokenOwner(String oldUser, String newUser)         throw CliCommandException;  I then tried to add a Javadoc comment by positioning the cursor in the method  name and right clicking. I used Source->Javadoc to generate the comment.  Instead of inserting the comment immediately above the new method declaration,  it inserted it at colum 22 of line 128, immediately following the partial  string "DOWN" in the variable declaration "DOWNLOADABLE".  Without doing anything else, I decided to see if I could produce a smaller  test case. First I used the undo command to remove the generated Javadoc  command which worked successfully. I then used the Create Interface wizard  which I accessed from the toolbar to create a new interface called  TestInterface. This was created in the same package as ICliCommand.java and  resulted in the file TestInterface.java which is also attached to this bug  report.  I next used copy and paste to copy lines 109-131 which included the new method  declaration changeTokenOwner into the file TestInterface.java. This succeeded.  My next step was to try and generate a Javadoc comment for the method  declaration for changeTokenOwner in TestInterface.java using the popup menu.  Instead of generating a method Javadoc comment and placing it immediately  ahead of the metod declaration for changeTokenOwner, it generated a  class/interface Javadoc comment and placed it at line 9 of TestInterface.java  immediately ahead of the existing Javadoc comment.  I then decided to check the Eclipse log so I directed Eclipse to shutdown.  Eclipse asked me if I wanted to save the two dirty files ICliCommand.java and  TestInterface.java and I said yes.  Once Eclipse closed (apparently normally) I fould that there was no .log file  at all in the .metadata. I had deleted the previous one so that I could start  with a new file using the new build.  I now restarted Eclipse and I found the following. The 3 lines I had typed in  entering the method declaration for changeTokenOwner had been lost in the file  ICliCommand.java. In the file TestInterface.java all the lines entered via  copy/paste were missing as well as the generated Javadoc comment.  I was able to reproduce this scenario three times in a row with the only  variable being the exact place where the generated Javadoc comment in  ICliCommand.java was mis-placed.

title: JavaCompletionProcessor: error message never shown
desc: form bug 31764  The API says that an error message is shown when computeCompletionProposals or  computeContextInformation return null, so only when no proposals are shown.  However, teh current code does only return an error message when the number of  corrections is > 0  public String getErrorMessage() { 	if (fNumberOfComputedResults == 0) 		return JavaUIMessages.getString ("JavaEditor.codeassist.noCompletions"); //$NON-NLS-1$ 	if (PreferenceConstants.getPreferenceStore().getBoolean (PreferenceConstants.CODEASSIST_FILL_ARGUMENT_NAMES)) { 		return fExperimentalCollector.getErrorMessage(); 	} else { 		return fCollector.getErrorMessage(); 	} }

title: [content assist] Support incremental content assist
desc: I've been spoiled by content assist.  What would be a great addition would be a  Unix-style "look ahead" invoked by the TAB key, like at a Unix Shell.  If non-whitespace characters appear to the left of the Caret, it is unlikely  that a TAB is going to be inserted in that line.  This is why I think it's ok  to use TAB for this.  Basically, pressing TAB will be equivalent to the combination of: Control+SPACE, followed by ENTER.  So, given: for (int i = 0; i < cols.length; i++) { 	Entry entry = cols[i]; 	double distance; 	 	if (entry.side == -1) { 		distance = Math.abs(baseRect.preciseX - entry.offset); 		if (distance < best) { 			bestSide = -1; 			best = dis<<CARET>>  Pressing the TAB key will insert "tance".

title: [misc] Text layout not correct
desc: When using fonts other than the default font the layout of characters does not match the  positions used by the editor.  The end of the line is often past the last displayed  character.  Clicking in the text does not result in changes being applied to the character  where the click occured.  This seems more pronounced with variable size fonts.  The  problem seemed to occur most often with the first comment line of a java doc comment.

title: RCP: Add marker action disabled for Java editor
desc: N20031111  Start fresh workspace and create a class in a Java project. The following actions are disabled: Edit > Add Bookmark... Edit > Add Task...  It works in the standard text editor.

title: code assist should help on your previous error
desc: Do code assist in the following code  public class Main {  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		new Date(). 	} }  Currently you get no help since Date is not defined.  Why don't we notice this  and try to do something.  If we would code assist on Date in this failed case  (and then code assist the next case?) it would do what I want/hope.

title: [typing] String constant split/auto-indent leaves carriage returns in file
desc: In Eclipse, when I press enter in the midst of a string constant, I end up with a file in which some of the lines end in a single carriage return (\r).  This (on Windows) causes problems with other things, such as our version control system.  (the singleton carriage returns get lost, leading to ugly looking code when someone else pulls a copy out of version control)  For example, if I have an almost blank file containing just these three lines:  public class TestEclipseStringBehavior {     public static String test = "Hello, World!"; }  and I then try to split the string constant by placing the cursor right after the comma (,) and pressing enter, the eclipse IDE shows:  public class TestEclipseStringBehavior {     public static String test = "Hello," +         " World!"; }  However, if I then save this file and look at it in something that is stricter about line endings (such as windows notepad), I see that after the "+" character is just a carriage return (\r), whereas all the other lines end in CRLF (\r\n), as they should.  The workaround of course is Source->Convert Line Delimiters To->CRLF.  However, that requires remembering that you've done something that would cause eclipse to use these incorrect line delimiters.  Something's odd in JavaStringAutoIndentStrategy - it uses the first legal line delimiter from the document to do its auto splitting.  Unfortunately, eclipse is sufficiently big that I can't track down which CVS module would have the code that implements IDocument on windows, or track down what other parts of eclipse erroneously assume that the first value returned by getLegalLineDelimiters() is what should be used to break a line.

title: auto format of switch() statement does not work as same as that of Source>Format menu's
desc: In Java Editor ,  when I input switch() statement, it is formated as follows    switch( flag ){       case 0:       some = code();       break;       case 1:   .........  But I use Source>Format function , it is formated as follows   switch( flag ){       case 0:           some = code();           break;       case 1: ............  And when I paste a sentence into switch() section, it is auto indented as follows,    switch( flag ){       case 0:       case 1:   .........      |      v   switch( flag ){       case 0:       some = code();       break;       case 1:   .........  I think it is a setting bug of auto indenter.

title: [navigation] Outline prompter is slow
desc: build I20031113  - with UI projects in source  - open type on ActionFactory (in org.eclipse.ui.actions) - Ctrl+O - it takes 4 seconds to come up on my laptop (T30)

title: [formatting][templates] template formatting fails if produced code is not valid java syntax
desc: I200311050952  using the following template ----------------------------- public ${enclosing_type}(${arguments})  {       ${cursor} } ----------------------------- I get the following error: !ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.ui 4 10001 Nov 17, 2003 14:26:29.847 !MESSAGE formatter failed to format (no edit returned). Will use unformatted  text instead. kind: 0, string: public SetViewer(arguments)  {       /*${cursor}*/ }  and the open and close brackets do not show up in the correct columns ( i.e  don't get formatted).

title: Print margin is in wrong location
desc: Eclipse 2.1 (RC1)  After changing my font to "Courier New", then turning on the Print Margin, I  had to realize that it was located in the wrong place (off by some characters)

title: [find/replace] Find/Replace has Find button disabled
desc: 20031119  1. create the following class: class A {   int MY_CONSTANT= 1;    int foo() {     return MY_CONSTANT;   } } 2. select 'MY_CONSTANT', press CTRL + F (Find/Replace) 3. have 'Whole word' enabled  -> 'Find' botton is disabled

title: [templates] Mouse click during doesn't remove link feedback
desc: 1) execute quick assist>local rename on a variable 2) execute quick assist>local rename on another variable ->the link feedback of the first variable is left around

title: [formatting] formatting adds extra tabs and line breaks
desc: i200311192030  Using the new formatter, formatting a selection will prepend a tab and add a new line break in the end.  The simple test case is to select a method body and format it. The first line will have and extra tab in the beggining, and a new break will be added in the end.

title: [save actions] Fix indentation save action in large file is very slow, blocking UI
desc: Created attachment 269384 [details] A project with a single, very large, source file. Editing and saving this file results in a very long save action.  When saving a very large source file, with lots of commented lines, the save action which corrects indentation takes very long.  In the attached example, a file with 18k lines takes about 2 to 3 minutes on a HP Z620 (RHEL 7.2).   Steps to reproduce:  1. Import project from attached archive. 2. Open source file SomeClass.java. 3. Un-comment any commented line, e.g. the second line "// aaa bbb ccccc". 4. Save the file. 5. Observe 2-3 minutes of blocked UI, until the file is saved.   Further information:  Original problem was observed with a 60k+ lines of code source file, containing constants (mostly commented out). Saving this took more than 10 minutes.   Eclipse version:  Eclipse Java EE IDE for Web Developers.  Version: Oxygen Release (4.7.0) Build id: 20170620-1800

title: [content assist] Rank most frequently used completion at top of each category
desc: When suggesting a completion, code completion should remember earlier  completions and promote those that have been used before to the top of the  list.  Some examples where this makes sense: - When using a class that has a fairly long name and that starts the same as  many other classes (usually connected...).  - When using a class that has a names mate in a different package. The  quintessential example is {java.awt.,java.util.}List. Usually the latter is  the desired, but it never comes on top.

title: [typing] Paste inserts partial string
desc: In some circumstances, when I paste, only part of the text on the clipboard is  inserted. For example, type the following into a Java method:                  double leftInset   = 42,                     topInset = ;  Make sure the second line is indented relative to the first one. Copy the  text 'leftInset' to the clipboard. You can verify this was copied OK by pasting  into Notepad. Position the insertion point just before the semicolon & paste.  You should see just 'Inset' pasted - the first four characters are omitted.

title: Add bookmark dialog: wording
desc: RC1  In the javaeditor annotation bar click right and choose 'Add Bookmark' from the content menu. A dialog shows up The label is 'Enter Bookmark name'. I think it should be 'Enter bookmark name:'

title: [navigation] M5 performance problems when scrolling using arrow down
desc: I have noticed a significant performance degradation between M3 and M5  when doing something as simple as scrolling through a java source file. My  workspace contains 5 projects, with a total of 4k or so java files.   In M5 I opened a java file, placed the cursor at the top of the file, and held  the down arrow until I hit the bottom of the file... Every 10 lines or so when  the cursor ends up on a type there is a pause where the cursor doesn't move,  and then it jumps back to life. This is quite annoying when trying to move  around in the file and get stuff done. I notice in the progress view when the  pauses occur the task "Java AST creation" is running and when the pause stops  the tasks is finished (or its marked as cancled).   Doing the same thing with M3 (same workspace, same settings) results in no  noticable pauses. M3 is quite zippy. I tried out M4 for a bit today and don't  notice the same severity of slow downs compared with M5... However I haven't  used M4 enough to have a good comparison.

title: Empty Bookmark name allowed but no bookmark added
desc: RC1  Select a word in the editor and choose 'Add bookmark' from the context menu on the annotation bar. As bookmark name enter a space. press ok  No bookmark is added

title: Incremental Code completion need defaul keybinding
desc: Add Ctrl+Shift as default key binding for incremental completion.

title: Ctrl+O not working
desc: RC 1    - JUnit setup  - open a Java file  - press Ctrl+O.     Observe: the outline pops up and closes without user action

title: Annotations: Current Instruction Pointer
desc: Its icon always shows up in the vertical bar, regardless of the setting of "show in vertical ruler"  I200312162000

title: Inconsistent menu structure
desc: The Source menu and the Source submenu of the editor context menu should be of  the same structure and sequence. See "Sort members" and "Format" for outliers.

title: [misc] Save in Editor is slow
desc: M6  - open a large file (e.g PushDownTests) - change something inside a method body - save   observe: CPU goes up to 100% for about 1 - 2 sec.  I have autobuild off

title: Problem indication fails when Error fixed
desc: In the Tasks each Error is automatically detected and entered in the proper way.  If I fix the Error, the previous marked Error remains still marked - in the  Tasks AND in the Code-Window.     e.g. Calling the Constructor f() where only f(int) is defined => Highligted and  marked. Changing to f(4) fixes the problem, but marks are Tasks remain.

title: [content assist] for static members in unresolved qualifying type should show deprecated type
desc: I20081125-0840  In a new class in jdt.ui, create a method and type 'Assert.isNo' and invoke content assist. You get 3 indistinguishable proposals for isNotNull(Object) in class Assert (bug 161242). 2 of the 3 classes are even deprecated, but this is not visible in the proposals list.  Proposals that import a type as side effect should also be rendered as deprecated if the type to import is deprecated (not only if the member itself is deprecated).

title: [templates] Template toarray not proposed
desc: I200401130800  return new DelegatingValidationStateChange(to<code assist>);  observe:  poposals don't contain an entry for the toarray templete

title: Using Emacs key bindings to navigate the code-completion window
desc: It be nice to use the Emacs bindings (ctrl-p, ctrl-n) to move up and down in the code completion window.  Currently these bindings make the cursor move around in the editor while the code completion window is open (which may be considered a bug in itself).

title: Read Only files: Strange behaviour of 'comment' action
desc: rc1 1. set a file to ready only. 2. Open the file an select a range 3. From the context menu choose 'comment'    all actions available 4. A error dialog pops up 'Problems editing file, xy is read-only' 5. open the context menu again: Comment is gone  6. From the Edit menu, select 'comment' , nothing happens (no error dialog)  Note that an entry is printed to the log !ENTRY org.eclipse.team.core 4 4 Feb 26, 2003 21:44:29.337 !MESSAGE File /org.eclipse.jdt.ui/src-jdt/org/eclipse/jdt/ui/JavaUI.java is read-only.

title: [reconciling] JavaMultiPassReconciler removes annotations
desc: I20040130 + plug-in export  Open a CU which has errors and warnings. Observe: the annotations in overview and annotation ruler are quickly visible and then get removed. This is caused by JavaMultiPassReconciler.

title: [typing] Wrap Java String doesn't wrap the pasted code as expected
desc: Using RC1, 1) Create a new class with the following source: public class B {  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		System.out.println(""); 	} }  2) Copy the contents of the main method. 3) Put the curson betweent he two double-quotes and paste the code. 4) The double quotes that you pasted in are not replaced with \".  The Java string wrapping should build a string from the code you paste in. And in this string " should be converted to \". This is the same problem for all escape characters.

title: Widget disposed errors in log from content assist
desc: I20040219  I have several widget disposed errors in my log, dating from yesterday's build, back to at least the Feb. 12 build.  I am having trouble pasting into mozilla, so I will attach the log file.

title: rc - source - comment is not compatible with undo action ctrl z
desc: If you select a piece of code, right click -> source -> comment you can not undo that action.  Probably a problem with other context menu commands.

title: [reconciling] Annotations disappear in multi-window setup
desc: I20040309  1. open the same CU in two windows 2. add a temporary error in one window 3. switch to the other window    observe: error is shown (OK) 4. start typing in a comment    observe: annotations go away (BAD)  This is probably a re-entrancy problem when reconciling

title: source -> comment command ignores undo buffer
desc: RC1: Use the source -> comment command to comment out one or more lines of java  code, pressing CTRL+Z does not undo the comment and has some funky behavior,  trying to undo something done while ago.  The source -> uncomment command appears to work correctly.

title: [misc] Label Decorators in Outline View block UI
desc: I20040325 MacOS 10.3.3  - make sure that Label Decorators are enabled - open class org.eclipse.swt.internal.carbon.OS - try to edit (click in text) Observe: you get the spinning beachball for 1 min 40 secs (on a 1.25 GHz PowerBook)  - close editor - turn off all Label Decorators - open OS again Observe: problem almost gone: the UI becomes resposive after 2 seconds

title: Pb when deleting "}" ...
desc: Type this text :  	public void init () 	{ 		put (); 	} 	}  Now, add "" between the () near the put. You will obtain this :  	public void init () 	{ 		put (""); 	} 	}  Now, go under for deleting the "}" and press backspace.  The "}" is not deleting, but the "" will desappears !  That's all.  I'm available for giving more information.  JMS.

title: Ctrl-Right at start of line moves only tab-wise (in M9)
desc: Java Editor, setting: tab indentation  When the caret is positioned at the start of a line, Ctrl-Right doesn't move it to the beginning of the first word anymore (as in M8), but only on tab.

title: Code Assist Popup is closed before a selection is made (M5, RC1)
desc: Versions: 2.1 M5 and RC1  The code assist popup will be visible (after typing a period after a class) for  about one second after which it is closed and the Eclipse Platform (the whole  IDE) loses focus.  This bug was NOT present in version 2.1 M4.

title: [projection] collapsing a foldable region puts caret to start of file
desc: RC2  - open this file:  package encoding;  public class LATIN1Class2 {     /**      * @return      */     private String הצ� ( )     {         // TODO Auto-generated method stub         return "הצ�";     }     /* (non-Javadoc)      * @see java.lang.Object#toString()      */     public String toString ( )     {         // TODO Auto-generated method stub         return "הצ�: " + הצ�();     } }   2. Go to the comment before the toString method 3. press Ctrl+NUMPAD_MINUS to fold the comment  -> expected: caret is at the beginning of the line (if within the folded-away code) or a the position where I was when collapsing (if on the first line of the folded region).  -> actual: caret is at start of file.

Open a CU, select it in the package explorer and invoke 'Format'    The file is left modified but not saved 4. Save the file, but when prompted to perform edit say 'no'. 5. title: Auto indent fails before a string
desc: Eclipse 2.1RC1, Windows 2000 Consider the following code:  public void test() {    callMethod(paramA, paramB, <cursor>"paramC", paramD); }  when you press Enter at the <cursor> position, editing continues at the  beginning of the next line rather than the correct indenting position. Pressing  Enter every other place produces the expected behaviour (it seems that the  problem only occurs when " is the next character).  This is similar as described in bug 31386, however I don't know whether it is a  duplicate.

title: [spell checking] tons of temporary spell check annotations
desc: I200406180010 + plug-in export for I200406180800  1. disable folding and enable spell checker 2. open AbstractTextEditor 3. goto verifyText 4. start typing some random text behind a }  observer the overview ruler: sometimes it is filled with spell checker annotations  Note: if you cannot reproduce try starting to type - wait shortly - then type again.

title: [misc] Occurrences have same layer as Search Results
desc: 3.0RC3  With default settings: - enable Mark Occurences - perform a local search on a local variable with many occurences - step through the search results -> hits change between Occurences and Search Result background colors

title: [content assit] Feature: Class name completion on "compressed form"
desc: The current completion feature is great, but with only the first letters of a class name, one often gets quite a long list of candidates. Given the Java convention of using CamelCase for names, I would like to be able to complete names using the "compressed" form of a class name, where only uppercase letters are relevant: "StringBuffer"'s compressed form would be "SB".  More specifically: on completion, if the text being completed consists only of uppercase letters, for example "SB", consider this as a "template" for the full name, and look in priority for class names of the form "S[a-z0-9_]+B[a-z0-9_]+.*". Then, if there is still an ambiguity and the user types another uppercase letter, say "B", restrict the candidate list to the ones corresponding to the template "SBC" (giving for example ScatteringByteChannel).  Examples:   SB<C-space> => StringBuffer (and others)   CNFE<C-space> => ClassNotFoundException (probably the only one)   STSTV<C-space> => StringToStringTableVector (here, typing "String<C-space>", which is one character longer, gives you dozens of candidates, the right one being almost at the end).

title: [spell checking][preferences] Dictionary is missing
desc: When spell-check is enabled, every word is marked as having been misspelt.  I  suppose that's because the dictionary is missing (or empty).

title: Quickfix via margin does offer fixes for multiple markers
desc: - Create Test.java below - Click on error icon in left margin - There is no import alternative available  The import quickfix is available via the task menu.   import java.awt.*; import java.awt.image.BufferStrategy; import java.awt.image.VolatileImage; import java.io.FileInputStream; import java.io.FileNotFoundException; import java.net.URL;  import javax.xml.bind.JAXBContext; import javax.xml.bind.JAXBException; import javax.xml.bind.Unmarshaller; public class Test { 	public void foo() 	{ 		ImageObserver foo=new ImageObserver() 		{ 			 		}; 	} }

title: [quick assist] Rename in workspace not available in compare editor
desc: Follow-up to bug 262393.  Underlying problem is that the IInvocationContext we get in QuickAssistProcessor#getAssists(..) does not offer a way to access the current JavaEditor.  LinkedNamesAssistProposal contains a similar shortcut to get the JavaEditor.

title: [implementation] Reconciling should be more robust
desc: Cheetah as of 20040625  In situations where the compiler/reconcile has bugs like in early Cheetah,  editor contents cannot be saved properly, also see bug 68557 for an example.  We should make our support more robust, and capture such failures as  JavaModelExceptions (similar to batch compiler handling).

title: Bad default modifier for Hyperlink style navigation on MacOS X
desc: M5 The default modifier for hyperlink style navigation is "Control" which doesn't work well on  MacOS X because here the Control modifier is used to simulate a right-click (opening the  context menu). The consequence of this is that if control is pressed the users gets the underlined text  style when hovering, but he cannot follow the link because a click results in opening the  context menu. The default on MacOS should be 'Command'

title: [painting] Stale completion highlighting after canceled completion
desc: Build: I20030304  This is with the "Insert completion" code assist preference turned off.  1) Start with the following type:  public class A { 	public void foo() { 		String s = "hello"; 		s.startsWith(""); 	} }  2) Position the cursor between "s" and "t" in the startsWith method call 3) Invoke code assist  Observe: the remainder of the method "tartsWith" is highlighted.  This is fine.  4) Single left click on the method "substring" in the completion list 5) Now single left click outside the code assit popup to cancel it.  Observe: the remainder of the method is still highlighted, even though code assist has been canceled.  The only way to get rid of the highlighting is to close and reopen the editor, or type inside the highlighted area.

title: [hovering] Show why there's no Javadoc
desc: Javadocs for methods, etc within the JRE display propery in the Javadoc View and in the code window  after appropriate delay; the external browser menu also works. User libraries don't work in the first two  cases, only the external browser works... (this confirms that the javadoc path is correct)

title: in the class outline view: group methods according to their visibility
desc: It should be possible to either sort or group the methods in the class outline  view according to their visibility.

title: Ctrl+Click feature became slow in 3.1
desc: I200409070800  Open the Java editor (as source), scroll down to end of file and then use Ctrl+Click feature.  Observe: it takes very long until the word gets blue and underlined.

title: Automatic method content assist broken when using minimal template
desc: I have:  class Foo implements Runnable { run<<CODE ASSIST>> }  If I remove the $TODO line from the Method Body template, then I get the  following generated when selecting run from code assist: /**  * @see java.lang.Runnable#run()  */ public void run();  This is wrong.  It should be: /**  * @see java.lang.Runnable#run()  */ public void run(){ }
