title: [syntax  highlighting] Last semantic highlighting position lost
desc: I200408170800  Using the CU below with Local Variable References higlighting enabled: - comment i's declaration - wait for reconciler to finish - uncomment i's declaration - wait for reconciler to finish -> i's reference is no longer highlighted  public class Test { 	public void foo() { 		int i= 0; 		int j= 0; 		j= i; 	} }

title: Java Example Editor looses all non-basic editing capabilities
desc: When checking out the Java Editor Example  (org.eclipse.ui.examples.javaeditor), building it and then launching a runtime  workbench, all hover texts, syntax coloring and doubleclick strategies do not  work.  Reason: The constructor of "org.eclipse.ui.editors.text.TextEditor"  calls "setSourceViewerConfiguration" with a "TextSourceViewerConfiguration",  thus overwriting the customized "JavaSourceViewerConfiguration" registered in  the API method "initializeEditor".  Fix: Move call to "setSourceViewerConfiguration" to the  method "initializeEditor" in class "org.eclipse.ui.editors.text.TextEditor"

title: [syntax highlighting] 'Abstract Method Invocation' highlighting also matches declaration
[hovering] Spelling quick fix "Ignore xx during current session" does not update editor from hover
desc: N20080423-2000  The spelling quick fix "Ignore xx during current session" does not work when invoked from the rich problem hover. Works fine via Ctrl+1. Nothing in the log.

title: [misc] find all sources of an exception
desc: Sometimes it is not quite clear at which points in code a caught exception originates. The scenario I would like to see is this:  - select a catch clause in a try/catch statement - open context menu, select "Open exception source hierarchy" - a hierarchy similar to the "Open call hierarchy" opens, showing all points in the try statement where the selected exception could come from. If the points are method calls (which they usually are), they could be expanded with points in that method from which the exception could come.

title: [save actions] Inline comments do not observe maximum line length
desc: Build Id: I20080422-0800 I have set up a personal formatter profile, with:  Window > Preferences > Java > Code Style > Formatter : Edit :   "Line Wrapping" : Maximum Width = 160, Wrap only when necessary  This profile is used in the save actions for formatting those lines of code that I have edited. Now this works nicely for Java code, but following line (one line in original):  	public final static String IMAGE_DIR_ELCL = IMAGE_DIR_ROOT + "elcl16/"; // enabled - size 16x16 //$NON-NLS-1$  wraps as follows on Save:  	public final static String IMAGE_DIR_ELCL = IMAGE_DIR_ROOT + "elcl16/"; // enabled 																			// - 																			// size 																			// 16x16 																			// //$NON-NLS-1$   That is, the inline comment at the end is wrapped one word per line. Which makes a warning appear, because the //$NON-NLS-1$ tag is no longer on the same line as the constant.   Workaround is to Edit > "Undo Save Action" after every save. That's making me crazy... please get it fixed!

title: [hovering] Hovers need some space on the left
desc: (pointed out by Philippe) when hovering over an error tick in the overview  ruler then there is no space on the left of the hover (see attached image)

title: [hovering] Turn types in Javadoc element headers into links
desc: I20080520-2000  In Javadoc hovers and the Javadoc view, we should also turn the types in an element header (method arguments, field type, type arguments, ...) into links. We once tried that, but all the blue and underlines looked too noisy.  The headers should look like today, but types should get underlines (and maybe change their color) when the user hovers over them.

title: Printing multiple files  - missing header information
desc: There does not seem to be any way to print source code that survives the "drop on the floor" test. That is, when I select and print multiple source files, each page is missing the filename and page number. If I get the pages out of order, it is very difficult to reassemble them in the correct sequence.

title: [preferences] Tooltip and info views background color clashes with editor colors
desc: I like black backgrounds.  I've changed my editor accordingly.  However, the declaration view shows a light yellow background.  Colors that show up well on black do not show up on light yellow.  This general assumption throughout JDT that the background for java code should be colorized against and arbitrary background is a consistent reocurring issue.  It's been a problem in diff viewers, various "popups" (and other places, I think).  They should either:  a) use the editor background b) not colorize the java code or c) let me set a background color for that usage explicitly.  In the case of Declaration view, I can certainly see the advantage in having the background NOT be the the same as the editor, so let me set that in the preferences.

title: [spell checking][implementation] PersistentSpellDictionary closes wrong stream
desc: CVS HEAD as of today (06/10/2008)  PersistentSpellDictonary has an OutputStreamWriter which is never used but closed in finally. Instead the FileOutputStream is used to write the file but is never closed.  Attached a little patch to remove the OutputStreamWriter and close the FOS instead.

title: Go to Previous target not acting like Go to Next target
desc: Go to Previous target is searching through unselected targets such as warnings.  The behavior is dissimilar from Go to Next target whose action is reflecting  the selection of the drop down to configure targets. The checkmarks for the two  are the same, but the behavior differs.

title: [content assist]  Parameter hint vanishes when moving cursor vertically
desc: I20080613-2000  When moving the cursor inside the same line, the parameter hint tooltip perfectly works by bolding the current parameter. But when the arguments list is splitted across several lines and I move the cursor the another line the popup vanishes.  Consider the following class: ----------------------------------- package A;  public class D {  	void foo(Object param1, Object param2, Object param3, Object param4) { 	} 	 	void bar() { 		Object ob = new Object(); 		foo(ob,	ob,   // works in horizontal mode 			ob,		  // but not in vertical 			ob); 	} } -----------------------------------  Placing the cursor in the first line of the foo invocation and calling the parameter hint everything is fine. But it should stay even if I hit the down/up arrow because I'm still inside the method argument list.

title: unwanted indents after if()/for()/while()....
desc: Since 3.0m3 (and one or two integration builds before it) i get an automatic indent after controll statements like if()+new line. So my code looks like this (only automatic indents):  public class Main { 	void someMethod() 	{ 		if(true) 			{ 				// this doesn't look good 			} 			else if(1==1) 				{ 					// this is getting even worse 				} 				// oh my god :( 	} }  After running the code formater the code looks like expected  public class Main { 	void someMethod() 	{ 		if (true) 		{ 			// this doesn't look good 		} 		else if (1 == 1) 		{ 			// this is getting even worse 		} 		// oh my god :( 	} }  If there is a switch i didn't didn't find: sorry. If not: please fix it asap

title: [content assist] uses arg0 when generating overriding method in same CU
desc: I20080617-2000  Content assist uses arg0 as parameter name when generating an overriding method in the same CU. Expected: Should reuse the parameter names from the super method, like 'Source > Override/Implement Methods...' does.  Works fine if the subclass is declared in a separate file.  To reproduce:  - create p/C.java: package p; public class C { 	void m(int a, int b) {} } class Sub extends C { 	 }  - content assist inside Sub - select m(..) => result: 	@Override 	void m(int arg0, int arg1) { 		// TODO Auto-generated method stub 		super.m(arg0, arg1); 	}

title: [templates] Template Invocation Can't be Forced
desc: In JBuilder, (at least way back when I was using it), you used control-j to  force a template.  It was different than code completion.  If you're in eclipse, and type for example "sy" then control-space, it pulls up  a bunch of options, with my template "system.out.." in about 20th place.  This  is annoying.  however, if I could do control-j to pop up *only* templates, it  would know it was the only choice and could auto-invoke it.  (I've had to do a  template named "zy" to get it to do this.. which is a dumb alternative)  I have  the same problem with many templates that have names similar to common java  class names. (unsup, illegalarg)  In short - a new keystroke for invoking *not* code complete and templates, but  to invoke *only* templates..

title: [misc] Mark occurrences: wrong/missing exit points for break to label
desc: I20080624-0800  Mark occurrences misses some exit points for break statements with a label argument. It even highlights the wrong closing brace if you select 'break stay;' here:  	public static void main(String[] args) { 		stay: if (true) { 			for (int i= 0; i < 5; i++) { 				System.out.println(i); 				if (i == 3) 					break stay; 			} 			System.out.println("after loop"); 			return; 		} 		System.out.println("Stayed!"); 	}  The problem is that BreakContinueTargetFinder#getLocationForClosingBrace(ASTNode) tries to be too smart in getOptionalBlock(..).  I think the best solution would be to change getLocationForClosingBrace(..) to just use the targetNode as maybeBlock. This would just select the last character of the target node. In rare cases (e.g. a 'do{}while();' loop), this would not select a '}' but the terminating ';' of the labeled statement (which is even better, IMO).

title: [painting] Background changes to yellow when pressing Ctrl in the Java editor
desc: I have not yet found a set of steps to predictably reproduce this, although it seems to be related to using the ctrl key (I frequently use ctrl-left and ctrl-right to move the cursor between words) in the Java editor over an extended period of time.  1. Whenever the ctrl key is pressed, all the text between the current cursor position and some seemingly random position in the file changes to orange-on-yellow (see screenshot 1). Releasing the ctrl key will sometimes change the text back.  2. Occasionally, releasing the ctrl key will not change the text back to normal, and the text colour will be permanently changed in portions of the file (see screenshot 2). Pressing ctrl additional times will simply discolour additional portions of the file. The Java editor must be closed and reopened before the text returns to normal.  Issue 2 is probably a bug, but it's possible that issue 1 is part of some feature that I'm unwittingly activating through some typo. If so, then it would be nice if this feature were disabled by default.

title: [hovering] Annotation attribute javadoc is not displayed
desc: Build ID: I20080617-2000  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create ExampleAnno.java:  public @interface ExampleAnno {     /**      * Some documentation.      */     String[] anAttribute(); }  2. Create Demo.java: public class Demo {      @ExampleAnno()     public void m() {             }  }  3. Place the cursor inside the parens for @ExampleAnno and bring up content assist (CTRL-SPACE).  Notice that anAttribute is listed, but the JavaDoc does not appear in the hover.   More information:

title: Comment Formatter should compare values using equals()
desc: Currently, the preference values are read and compared by reference, which only works in special circumstances.

title: [content assist] prefix complete casted method proposals
desc: Created attachment 112697 [details] assist_diff.txt  Taken from bug 208540:  - enable incremental completion - invoke content assist after ( | = caret):  ----------------------------------     void m(Object o) {         if (o instanceof Integer)             o.g| ----------------------------------  - expected: prefix completed to "o.get", proposals for getClass and getInteger methods - actual: no prefix completion, the proposal selector opens directly  --  Also, the fix for #208540 added a small change when compared to 3.3 to the "semi case sensitive" matching done by prefix completion:  - enable incremental completion - invoke content assist after ( | = caret):  ----------------------------------     void m(int indexCount) {         ind| ----------------------------------  - expected: incremental completion detects the sole case sensitve match for the   'indexCount' parameter and applies the proposal (3.3 behavior) - actual: the proposal selector opens and shows all kinds of types like IndexOutOfBoundsException  The case matching algorithm is arguably peculiar - but the case outlined above bugs me frequently.  The attached patch fixes the two problems described and adds tests, also for #208540. The patch restores one part of the previous fix for #208540 and overwrites getPrefixCompletionStart in JavaMethodCompletionProposal for METHOD_REF_WITH_CASTED_RECEIVER proposals.

title: [EditorMgmt] Blank outliner when opening/switching to editor
desc: Build 20040303 - multiple windows  No exact steps sorry. The problem is that sometimes when opening an editor  (ctrl-shift-T) or switching to an existing one will bring it to front, but the  outliner doesn't refresh properly. It remains blank. Usually, closing the editor and reopening will make the outline show up after a  few attempts.

title: [implementation] AbstractJavaCompletionProposal leaks file handle
desc: Current HEAD  AbstractJavaCompletitionProposal#getCSSStyles forgets to close the input stream while reading the css file.

title: [typing] Starting Javadoc comment inserts @param tags for next method
desc: build I20040318  - open type TrimLayout - before method setSpacing, start a new method by typing a Javadoc comment - you get @param tags for the next method (even though it has its own Javadoc)  For example: Type this: 	/**<Enter>  Before this: 	/** 	 * Sets the empty space surrounding the center area. This whitespace is 	 * located between the trim and the central widget. 	 */ 	public void setSpacing(int left, int right, int top, int bottom) { 		leftSpacing = left; 		rightSpacing = right; 		topSpacing = top; 		bottomSpacing = bottom; 	}  You get: 	/** 	 *  	 * @param left 	 * @param right 	 * @param top 	 * @param bottom 	 */

title: [misc] Status line does not show problem message any more
desc: I20081014-1600, was OK in 3.4.1  Status line does not show problem message any more when the caret is in a range with squiggly lines.  Example:  package xy; public class Try { 	unresolved m() { 		, 	} }

title: Infinite loop keeps showing error dialog
desc: build N20040322   I had a few editor open in the java perspective when I attempted to open  org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Decorations  using Ctrl+Shift+T,  but (by mistake) I  open java.awt.font.Decoration (class file).  A error dialog pop-up with the message: ERROR: Java AST creation: An internal error occurred during: "Java AST  creation".  Every time a close the dialog it comes back up. I restart Eclipse but the  dialog would this be there, luckly the dialog is not modal so I could close  the editor behind making it go away.

title: [navigation] Reading occurency markers overlap writing markers
desc: A very nice feature of the new Eclispe version is the different colouring of variables when they are just read or written. So I marked read occurrences as green markers and write occurrences as red markers. Hunting a bug in my code, I couldn't find the problem where a variable suddenly changed its value as I just inspected the red markers. Finally after step-by-step debugging I noticed another line in the code that writes the variable     pDest.amount = pSource.amount;  These are 2 different instances pDest, pSource from the same class. Now, the variable "amount" is colored red on the left side and green on the right site - but the occurences marker just shows a green marker - probably because the red write marker is covered by the green (?) ...

title: [painting] Reusing Editors does not fully reset editor
desc: I200405190010  0. set to have at most 1 editor and set folding off for new editors 1. open a file from CVS Repository view 2. open a normal CU 3. add an error Observe: no error shown (reconciler not started?)  4. close all 5. open a normal CU which has errors and/or warnings 6. enable folding for this CU 7. open a file from repository Observe: folding annotations, errors and warnings hang around

desc: I20081125-0840.  While doing the dead-code analysis I found this code in org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.javadoc.JavadocLinkTypeCompletionProposal.computeReplacementString():  The else-branch is never executed.

title: [syntax highlighting] highlight numbers
desc: In 3.0, the java editor has supported operator..... etc. much more than 2.1.3. But it has not support highlight number.  Hope to enhance this feature.

title: [content assist] FUP of bug 336451: Add a regression test
desc: HEAD. After the fix for bug 336451, content assist no longer throws a CCE exception. But its not possible to test it with content assist tests inside JDT/Core since the problem was with compiler bindings, which are only used when code complete is invoked from outside.  It will be good to have a regression test for this case.  public class EclipseTest {     private static interface InvokerIF{         public <T extends ArgIF> T invoke(T arg) throws Exception;     }      private static class Invoker implements InvokerIF{         public <T extends ArgIF> T invoke(T arg){             return arg;         }     }      private static interface ArgIF{     }      private static interface ArgIF2<C> extends ArgIF{      }     private static class ArgImpl<C> implements ArgIF2<C>{         public ArgImpl() {             super();         }     }     public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {         InvokerIF test = new Invoker();         test.invoke(new ArgImpl[CTRL-SPC])     } }

title: [content assist] full qualification proposal hides constructor proposal
desc: HEAD  Settings: Default + Insert common prefixes... + Insert best guessed arguments  - have:  package p; public class C {         void m() {                 new Vecto|         } }  - put caret at | - Ctrl+Space  => changes line to 		new java.util.Vector|  => expected: 		new Vector| or 		new Vector(|); and content assist for constructor proposals.  I would always favor constructor proposals over explicit qualification proposals after "new xxx".

title: Find and Replace in selected lines not limited to selected lines
desc: Regarding 3.0 M9:  Performing a simple string replace in a Java file in a selected block of text  with "Selected Lines" checked does not limit the replaced text to only the  selected block, the next occurrence is also replaced. For example  >>> Selection starts here <<<     if (getFoo() == null) {         goo = "No Foo!";     } else {         goo = getFoo()     } >>> Selection ends here <<<     ...more code in file...     setFoo("Example"); // next occurrence of "Foo" text in code     ...  Performing a Find/Replace with selected lines enabled replacing "Foo"  with "Bar" then call to setFoo() is changed to setBar(). This happens  whether "Wrap Search" is selecetd or not (I tried that as a test). Other  occurences of "Foo" in that file are NOT changed, only the next occurrence  after the selected text is changed.  This behavior is NOT exhibited when replacing text in the Text Editor only in  the Java Editor.

title: Remove LineBreakingReader
desc: +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #264118 +++  Looks like JDT may have the same problem PDE has... an unused LineBreakingReader.  org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.LineBreakingReader  I'm marking this as major as having an unused class ship with the SDK is always tragic. Although I may have missed a use of this class, I've had enough wine tonight.

title: [preferences] annotations don't appear in the vertical ruller
desc: 3.0 RC1  - start with having the warning annotations visible in the vertical ruller - turn the warning annotations to be not visible in vertical ruller (from  Preferences/Workbench/Editors/Annotations). Hit Apply. - switch the warning annotations to be visible again in the vertical ruller =>  they won't appear in the ruller unles you close the editor and reopen it.   The same things happens with any kind of annotations not only warning  annotations.  Build id: 200405290105

title: [navigation][compare] Quick Outline does not select current element if no resource
desc: I20090203-1200  In Java compare editors, the Quick Outline does not initially select the current element in remote editor panes.

title: '#' should be a default auto activation trigger for javadoc content assist
desc: '#' should be a default auto activation trigger for javadoc content assist, since we offer code assist in situations like /** @see Vector#<caret_here> */.  IMO, we should make all these characters auto activation triggers: "@#.<".

title: [nls tooling] Externalize Strings wizard always defaults to the "legacy" mechanism
desc: The Externalize Strings wizard offers the option "Use Eclipse's string externalization mechanism" which is a superior choice. However, it does not default to that option when available nor does it remember the user's selection of that option for future invocations of the wizard. It should be encouraging use of the newer mechanism, especially since converting form the old to the new is a tedious manual process.

title: [typing] Incorrect code formatting on Paste
desc: Pasting a JavaDoc comment into the following source should result in a JavaDoc comment which is not indented. This is because my formatting options specify to NOT indent class members. /******************************************************************************* * Copyright (c) 2000, 2003 IBM Corporation and others. * All rights reserved. This program and the accompanying materials * are made available under the terms of the Common Public License v1.0 * which accompanies this distribution, and is available at * http://www.eclipse.org/legal/cpl-v10.html * * Contributors: * IBM Corporation - initial API and implementation *******************************************************************************/ package org.eclipse.gef.ui.actions; import java.text.MessageFormat; import org.eclipse.ui.*; import org.eclipse.ui.IEditorPart; import org.eclipse.ui.ISharedImages; import org.eclipse.ui.actions.ActionFactory; import org.eclipse.ui.internal.WorkbenchImages; import org.eclipse.gef.commands.Command; import org.eclipse.gef.internal.GEFMessages; /** * An action to redo the last command. */ public class RedoAction extends StackAction { <> public RedoAction(IWorkbenchPart editor) { super(editor); } AND THEN paste the following text: /** * Creates a RedoAction and associates it with the * given editor. * * @param editor The editor this action is associated with. */ NOTE the text is indented incorrectly.

title: [implementation][content assist] Broken extension point XSD and UI: proposalSorter is missing activate attribute
desc: Build ID: M20080911-1700  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Add javaCompletionProposalSorters extension point 2. Add proposalSorter 3. Implement your proposal sorter 4. Test sorter: Open preferences and choose your sorter (Java->Editor->Content Assist->Sort proposals) 5. Even though it is chosen, your sorter will not execute and you can see NPE in log: org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.java.ProposalSorterHandle.sortProposals(ProposalSorterHandle.java:191)   More information: The reason why it doesn't work is that ProposalSorterHandle instance has "activate" field set to false. To fix this, you must manually edit your plugin.xml and add activate="true" attribute to proposalSorter element.  XSD should be enhanced to contain 'activate' attribute and UI should be enhanced to offer activate combo with true/false as other extensions do (e.g. javaCompletionProposalComputer).

title: Search for file occurences keybinding doesn't work
desc: RC3 - 20040622:00:10  I opened org.eclipse.ui.examples.jobs.views.JobsView added a field to the classes saved the file (note at this point there are no errors or warnings in the file) then clicked on another existing field and pressed CTRl+SHIFT+U. All I got was a beep. I get this a lot and it is really annoying because I rely on this search function, I love it!   The message in the status line when this happens is "element is not a java element".   So here are the exact steps to reproduce 100% of the time (note that I have analyse annotations while typing turned off): 1. open JobsViews (org.eclipse.ui.examples.jobs plugin) 2. click on userField attribute and ctrl+shirt+u works. 3. add an attribute to the end of the Button fields. Don't save yet. 4. Click on another attribute and ctrl+shirt+u. Beep. Nothing happens. 4. save and the file compiles without errors. 5. click on userField again and then ctrl+shirt+u. It no longer works and the above error message is shown in the status line.   Closing and then opening the editor will get you out of this state. but this is happening all the time and at first I thought it was a  keybinding problem, but it actually looks like a java search issue.

title: tag projects changed since I20090421-0930 build - jdt text
desc: Because of bug 274181, the published jar files were missing entries for directories during this week's milestone builds.    As a result, teams will need to tag projects that have changed since I20090429-0930.  Otherwise, the builds will contain the old jars with missing directory entries.  Features and test bundles do NOT need to be changed.   Here are the bundles for jdt text   org.eclipse.text org.eclipse.jface.text org.eclipse.ui.workbench.texteditor org.eclipse.ui.editors org.eclipse.core.filebuffers org.eclipse.ui.examples.javaeditor

title: [navigation] Open with "Show Selected Element Only" does not narrow down in single-click mode
desc: I have "Show Selected Element Only" selected in my Type Hierarchy perspective.  When I open a Type Hierarchy and click on an element in the Hierarchy pane, the Editor pane highlights that element in the source, but doesn't just show that element--it's still showing the entire source.  If I then click in the Editor pane, the view suddenly changes to just that element.

title: [hovering] Improper hover triggered due to bad hover order
desc: Created attachment 151903 [details] Proposed fix  Sometimes, the JDT debug hover does not show during a debug session.  Instead, it is the Source hover that is shown.  To reproduce: 1- start eclipse without activating the org.eclipse.jdt.debug plugin.  To do this, start in the Java perspective, without any debugging views open. 2- Select a java editor and hover over a variable.  The Source hover will trigger. 3- launch a java debug session 4- during that session hover over a variable in the editor.  You will again see the Source hover instead of the Debug hover.  The way that BestMatchHover decides which hover to use is by going through each hover sequentially to find the first one that will return an output.  This implies that the order in which the hovers are queried is very important.  The bug is caused by the fact that if a plugin is not activated, its hover is not added to the hover list of BestMatchHover right away, but will be added later, once the plugin is activated.  And when it is finally added it is put at the end of the list, losing its proper position.  This is because on the step 2, the debug plugin was not active so did not create the debug hover.  On step 4, the debug hover is finally created, but it is added to the end of the hover list, after the Source hover.  The attached patch proposes a fix.  The patch keeps the API the same even though the class was internal.  I also tried to keep performance as least impacted as possible, although there is an impact; however, the list of hovers is so small that it should not matter.  Note that I found this problem because we had an exact copy of BestMatchHover in the CDT, and that is where I saw and fixed the problem (bug 294812)

title: Error using Help: org_eclipse_jdt_ui_javaEditorTextHover.html not found

title: "Preferences..." menu item in Java editor does not have accelerator added to it.
desc: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.15) Gecko/2009101601 Firefox/3.0.15 Build Identifier: Eclipse 3.4.2 - Build Id: M20090211-1700  Using 3.4.2 Eclipse.  a) Navigate to Java Editor b) Right Click using keyboard c) Bug:  The "Preferences..." menu item is not having any accelerator.  Accelerator is required to meet accessibility.  This issue also seen in other Eclipse editors like html editor. Right click these editors, one can see all the context menu having accelerators,but the menu item " Preferences..." does not have any accelerator attached to it..   I am not sure if this is by design or a bug.   Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Navigate to Java Editor 2. Right Click using keyboard in Java editor 3. Bug:  The "Preferences..." menu item is not having any accelerator.

title: [hovering] @see method link in Javadoc doesn't work correctly if the method is in superclass
desc: Consider the following 2 classes:  public class ClassParent { 	public void foo1() { 	} }  public class ClassChild extends ClassParent{ 	/** 	 * @see #foo1() 	 */ 	public void foo2() { 		foo1(); 	} }  Steps to reproduce: 1) Open ClassChild and select method foo2 2) In the javadoc view, under the See Also section there is link to method foo1, click on foo1 link. The javadoc for ClassChild opens instead of the doc for foo1.  Selecting foo1 in @see #foo1 in the Java editor shows the javadoc correctly in the javadoc view.

title: [syntax highlighting] Syntax coloring for type names
desc: Lots of things can be given different colours in the syntax colouring, but type names can't as far as I can see. They can be given a non-default colour using "others", but nothing particular for *just* type names. I would imagine this should be relatively easy to implement.  What would be harder to implement, but possibly very useful, would be the ability to colour type names differently based on where the type is defined - eg one colour for JRE system libraries, one colour for extra jar files, one colour for other projects, and a final colour for "this" project. Call me a dreamer :)

title: [implementation][content assist] Use enhanced for loop for CompletionProposalCollector and CompletionProposalCategory
desc: I suggest to use the foreach loop in ContentAssistProcessor. Patch to follow soon.

desc: public class X { 	{ 		Y.callMe(); // StrikeThrough rendered - correct. 	} 	public static void main(String[] args) { 		Runnable r = () -> { 			Y.callMe();// PROBLEM: No Strikethrough 		}; 		System.out.println(r); 	} } class Y { 	@Deprecated 	public static void callMe() {} }  Ref the PROBLEM comment above (followup to bug 41255 comment 3)

title: Suggestion to align "Additional Save actions" with the desired code Eclipse contribution guidelines
desc: Created attachment 237386 [details] Setting  I think most Eclipse projects (at least Eclipse platform, EGit and e4) ask their contributors to remove trailing whitespace from their contributions.  I suggest to add "Remove trailing white space on all lines" to the default Additional save actions.   I also think that "Use modifier final where possible" for private fields is currently not desired by the Eclipse projects.   This would result in setting similar to the attached screenshot.  Would JDT accept a patch for this change?

title: [key binding] "Expand Selection to > Enclosing Element" hard to use in Luna
desc: Previous to Luna, the default keyboard accelerator for Select Enclosing Element was ⌃⇧↑, which was already pretty difficult to type, especially on a laptop keyboard where the fn key gets in the way. (The equivalent action in IntelliJ is bound to ⌘W.) Since Mavericks now stolen that key combination to something useless, the default keybinding in Luna was changed to ⌃⌥⇧↑. Unfortunately, this is almost impossible to get your fingers onto, at least on a laptop. Of course the user can change this, but there's no reason to not provide something a bit more comfortable by default. I recommend the following _much_ more ergonomic combinations:  - ⌃⇞ for Select Enclosing Element, and - ⌃⇟ for Restore Last Selection.  It's actually *very* easy to type these combinations on a Mac laptop (it's fn+control+uparrow and fn+control+downarrow) since the fn and control keys are right next to each other.

title: [spell checking] Add more words to the spelling dictionary
desc: The word "replenishment" in a text entry area is reported as incorrectly spelled.    -- Configuration Details -- Product: Eclipse 4.5.2.20160218-0600 (org.eclipse.epp.package.java.product) Installed Features:  org.eclipse.platform 4.5.2.v20160212-1500

title: [projection] Folding takes a long time to disable on StyledText.java
desc: I20050401-1645, slower machine (P3-733)  1. Open SWT's StyledText.java 2. Enable code folding from the context menu on the annotation bar 3. Disable code folding from the context menu on the annotation bar  Eclipse will now hang for 30-40 seconds on my machine.

title: [templates] Change SWT Browser template to not propose SWT.MOZILLA style
desc: Support for Xulrunner/mozilla is being removed in SWT in bug 518542 . Template has to be fixed to not propose using it anymore.

title: [spell checking] Enabling/Disabling spelling does not effect open files
desc: 3.1 M6  Enabing/Disabling spelling does not update the UI for files which are open. It's required to close and reopen the file.

title: [13] Text Block: Return after """ place caret on next line not after """;
desc: [13] Text Block: Return after """place caret on next line not after """;

title: [typing] Javadoc of overriding methods no longer created
desc: When I stepped up to M6, the "javadoc" of overriding methods (i.e. methods that are overriding an inherited method or implementing an interface method) were no longer being produced.  For example if you typed "/*" and then hit enter, it use to produce:  /* (non-javadoc)  * @see java.lang.Runnable#run()  */  It isn't doing that now. Has this function been removed?  Thanks, Rich

title: [preferences] 'Fill argument names on method completion' should not mention methods
desc: I20050509-2000 (M7 test pass)  the preference is also valid for type parameters  > rename to 'Fill argument names'  possible M7 candidate

title: Templates for constructor
desc: When I have an existing constructor within a class, which has a single line  comment and I attempt to convert this comment to a multi lie comment, it  inserts the 'typecomment' tempalte. In addition, the comment is not correctly  indented.  For example:  before: /**  * My typecomment  */ public class MyClass {     /** my constructor */     public MyClass() {     } }  after (placing cursor before 'my contructor' and hitting enter): /**  * My typecomment  */ public class MyClass {     /**   * My typecomment  */ my constructor */     public MyClass() {     } }

title: Wrong ranking of 'null' proposal during argument guessing [code assist]
desc: I20050509-2010 + JDT UI export  Steps to reproduce: - Consider the attached class - Try out method completion with argument guessing      public void setNachname(String nachname) {         setVorname<Ctrl+Space>         this.nachname = nachname;     }  -> Default proposal is 'null', a better guess would be nachname (although in  this case probably not ;-))

title: Inconsistent hyperlink descriptions in Java Editor preference page [preferences]
desc: I20050509-2010:  Typing: Hover of compiler warnings and spell checking preferences links show  same description  Code Assist: Missing hover for restricted references link  Syntax Coloring: Wrong description for text editors link

title: [implementation] Compiler error prevents further development
desc: Build 20050509  JDT/Text counterpart of bug 94945. See steps in other PR.

title: [5.0][content assist] Content assist popup disappears while completing the statically imported method name
desc: I20050513-0010  Steps to reproduce: - Create a new Class "Foo" - Type "import static java.lang.Math." - Press Ctrl+Space - Type "a"  -> Instead of constraining the proposals to all members with prefix a, the  popup closes

title: [nls tooling] External Strings doesn't use validateEdit
desc: I tried to externalize some strings in the CVS UI plugin. It failed because my  message class (CVSUIMessages) was read only. The tool should use validateEdit  to make the file writtable.

title: [CellEditors] [nls tooling] Strange selection behaviour in the NLS table
desc: M7  1. open an already translated file with lots of strings in the NLS wizard, e.g. UserLibraryPreferencePage 2. select the first value so that the cell ediotor appears 3. use the scroll bar to scoll so that the (still selected) entry is not visible anymore 4. select a new entry   -> the table suddendly scrolls and a different entry than intended gets the selection

title: [5.0][content assist] toarray template inserted as content assist method argument guess
desc: from bug 95785:  N20050518-0010  - have 'Fill argument names on completion' and 'Guess filled method arguments' enabled  - in the method below (in a 5.0 project), execute contant assist after toArray and choose "toArray(Object[] a)":     public void test(java.util.List aList){         aList.toArray     }  => the line now reads:         aList.toArray(toarray - convert collection to array)

title: [implementation] OperationCanceledException gets logged
desc: N20050521-0010  OperationCanceledException gets logged if reconcile is canceled during Java editor reconcile or if AST creation is canceled during AST Provider's AST creation.

title: [content assist] misleading proposals
desc: N20050523  - In the following code, invoke code assist at the caret (|). Note the verbose 'capture-of' proposals. We used to filter the display strings using a heuristic in M6, but capture support broke the heuristic.   Propose to adapt to the capture support in generics, as these verbose proposals are misleading. For example, 'capture-of ?' is a type constraint that is only met by the null type. We should display the simplest string that is possible to avoid confusion.  Fix is ready, propose for RC1.  --  import java.util.List;  public class Generics { 	void method(List<?> star) { 		star. 	} }

title: [misc] Shift Left/Right show up in the context menu
desc: These actions should not be shown in the short cut menu since they have a  prominent short-cut.

title: [navigation] Last '}' sometimes not flagged as exit point
desc: N20050523-0010  Example:  	void hasTwoExitPoints(int i) { 		if (i < 0) 			throw new RuntimeException("i"); 	}

title: Enabling Annotation Roll-overs has side-effects
desc: I2004032400800  The preference says that I does not affect open editors, hover it breaks quick fix in the already open editors.

desc: Assume "Statements within blocks" is set in the Identation tab in the Code Formatter preference panel.  (I'll try to attach my style.) In that case Source->Format will produce the following (correct):  public class Foo {   public static void main (String[] args)   {     if (false)       {         args[0] = "12";       }   } }  Now got to the line with the assignment and do Ctrl-I. The result is different and wrong:      if (false)       {       args[0] = "12";       }

desc: Open SWT's Scrollable on the Mac OS. Press Command+O twice, and type "isDispo".  Widget#isDisposed() should be displayed, but is not.  I'm having this problem it lots of places.

title: Auto close comment
desc: When typing "/**" and then "<enter>" comment should close automatically. This is very useful when typing Javadoc comments. Example: /**<enter> Transforms to: /**  * <cursor here>  */

title: Code assist could show static methods|fields with different icons
desc: It would be good if one could distinguish between static methods and normal  methods within the code assist. Eg. Thread.sleep(xxx) is static, but if you use Thread t=Thread.current(); t.sleep(xxx); you could think is local method.

title: [syntax highlighting] Improper display of custom tags
desc: N20050525-0010  Spawned from bug 22285. See there for an initial patch and comments to improve it.

title: [content assist] don't show templates in restricted situations
desc: I20050527-0010  There are some situations where only very few code completions make sense.  - Within a generic wildcard signature after the '?', where only the 'extends' and 'super' keywords make sense (bug 93119).  - Within the modifiers of a method, where only modifiers make sense  We should try to avoid showing templates in these situations. See bug 93119 - we should not show the 'else' and 'elseif' templates in these cases, or at least rank them lower than the correct keywords.  Should investigate whether there is an easy fix for RC2 that does not break custom templates.

title: [implementation] Properties File editor not associated with content type
desc: 3.1 RC1  Properties File editor not associated with content type

title: add alternate shortcut for "content-assist"
desc: <ctrl-space> is used for mode switch in Asian language. So in  Chinese/Japanese/Korean OS, application will never receive <ctrl-space> key,  <ctrl-space> "the key combination" will never work.  This actually documented in your http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/~checkout~/platform-ui- home/accessibility/tips.html  I would suggest add an alternate shortcut <ctrl-~> for "content assist"  besides <ctrl-space>. That will make our life much easier.  I know eclipse has some mechanism for user to add shortcut for some actions. (by editting some config file in the .metadata directory)  But "content assist" is one of the most frequently used command, add  some "defaults" will be much better than letting every Chinese/Korean/Japanese  user to do that by themselves.

title: [templates] iterable_element gives up on collection of generic types
desc: In RC1.  Create this method:  	private static void count(Class<?>... classes) { 		fore 	}  The template completion suggests "name" as the name of the element variable.    Taking out the type parameter gives  	private static void count(Class... classes) { 		fore 	}  Here, the template suggests "class1", which is much nicer.

title: [preferences] Java Hovers page missing mnemonics
desc: RC1  The Java Hovers page has no mnemonic for the Description field.

title: JavaDoc comment completion
desc: When I type /** and hit enter, the code completion should kick in and be the  equivalent of right clicking and hitting Source/JavaDoc

title: Pref Page Java/Editor/Code Assist/Sorting and Filtering - mnemonics
desc: Hide forbidden refrences Hide discouraged refrences  both have no mnemonic; suggest 'r' and 'c'

title: [preferences] Pref Page Java/Editor/Linked Mode - problems
desc: "Show in text as" should have a mnemonic; suggest 's'  "Color" label and "Show in text as" check box should be left aligned.

title: timestamp varibale use wrong countycode
desc: In Templates I can define and use Templates using actual date and time. The  format inserted is a wrong american format. Because I cannot find any  preferences to force a format, I assume that you get the format from the OS. In  my OS (Systemsteuerung - Ländereinstellung in engl. perhaps Controlpanel -  Country...) I used German as Default Country and the format to date and time  respectively.

title: [preferences] Pref Page Java/Editor/Syntax Coloring - Color label enablement
desc: The "Color:" label should be disabled when the color button is disabled.

title: [preferences] Pref Page Java/Editor/Templates - mnemonic
desc: "Preview" should have a mnemonic; suggest 'w'

title: incorrect handling of auto-string-closing in linked positions
desc: 0916.1 plugin export  1. package p; public class A{ 	void f(String hola) { 	} }  2. enter somewhere f<<CODE ASSIST HERE  3. choose the first entry - you get f(hola) << hola is selected and underlined  4. type "" fast  5. you get f(""a) - the last character is always left there

title: [preferences] Pref Page Java/Editor/Typing  - dialog font problem
desc: Open pref page.  Click on "formatter prefrence page".  Create a new formatter with a indention of 8.  OK.  Insure the new formatter is selected in the combo.  Click on Apply.  Switch back to Java/Editor/Typing observe the message does not use the dialog font anymore.

title: Linked Mode: Want to define where to focus
desc: 20021022 I added a new feature that starts the linked mode on all usages of a variable. e.g. int i; i= 1; i++;  would link all 3 occurrences of i, so when edited, all 3 references are  changed simultanously.  Problem is that the liked mode does not allow me to set the focus (where to  edit) to e.g. the 'i' in 'i++'. The linked mode only allows to edit the top  most linked position ('int i'). The feature can be invoked on any reference. Jumping to the top not so ideal.

title: [preferences] Pref Page Java/Editor/Typing - problems
desc: "Adjust indention" shares 'a' with "Apply"; suggest 'i'  The group labels should not have colons.

title: [preferences] Pref Page Java/Properties File Editor - mnemonic
desc: "Preview" should have a mnemonic; suggest 'w'

title: [typing] CompilationUnitEditor.TabConvertor should use project dependent formatter settings
desc: with 3.1 RC1, In the code formatter I set tab policy to spaces only, indentation size = 2, and tab size = 8. when I hit the tab key, 2 spaces are added to the line instead of going to an 8 space (tab) boundary.

title: [typing] Correct Indentation breaks Comment if it contains  "/*"
desc: If a multiline comment contains the sequence "/*" (slash,asterix) the comment is broken at the first line when indentaion is corrected. Example: /** * test comment *  * never use "/*" in comments! */  using correct indentation leads to /**  */ * test comment *  * never use "/*" in comments! */

title: Auto-indent levels broken for cut and paste
desc: On M3:  1) Double-click on the opening brace '{' of a method. 2) Cut the method body. 3) Paste the method body.  Problem: indentation is mangled incorrectly.

title: Java>Editor>Templetes does not affect at interface creation
desc: Menu: Preference>Java>Editor>Templetes   'filecomment' or 'typecomment' does not affect  when interface is created.  It(typecomment) affects for class.  Though I changed these comment format from default, eclipse 2.1 M5 generates as follows --------------------from here--------------------- /*  * Created on 2003/02/13  *  * To change this generated comment go to   * Window>Preferences>Java>Code Generation>Code Template  */ --------------------till here----------------------

title: [syntax highlighting] semantic highlighting broken when using "convert to new for loop"
desc: I20050610-0010 (no regression, though - just exposed by the quick fix)  - In the code below, execute the "convert to new for loop" quick fix - undo -> note that the 'for' keyword is wrongly colored. -> subsequent reconciles do not correct the failure -> only doing a major change (cutting and pasting entire method, closing editor..) corrects the problem  class Test{ 	void m() { 		LinkedList<Number> list = null; 		for (Iterator it = list.iterator(); it.hasNext();) { 			Number num = (Number) it.next(); 			System.out.println(num.intValue()); 		} 	} }  Code inspection revealed that SemanticHighlightingPresenter.contain() relies on positions being disjoint, which is not true in this case: the quick fix modifies the document in a way that produces many positions at the same offset/length.  A fix would change indexOf() to check all positions at a certain offset instead of the index returned. Need to talk to Christof about whether the position updater might be doing the wrong thing...

title: Link not recolor on paste
desc: I20021127  - copy some text - position the I beam on a line where you want to paste - position the cursor over a type name - press Ctrl to get the link highlighting - press V to paste the text  observe: the link disappears but the type name is still rendered in blue.

title: [preferences] search keyword improvements
desc: 3.1 RC2  This is an umbrella PR to capture all changes to preference page search keywords.

title: [preferences] Java Editor preference page should have a link to Text Editor
desc: I20050610-1757 (3.1RC2)  The Java Editor preference page has lost its link to the Text Editor preference page. The link should look like the one from the Properties File Editor prefs page.

title: [navigation] Outliner doesn't highlight the name of the package declaration for package-info
desc: RC2.  1) Create a project P with src/bin as source/output folders 2) Create a package 'p' 3) Create a file in this package that contains: @java.lang.Deprecated package p;  Click on the package declaration in the outliner and you get the position of the 'p' in Deprecated.  It looks like the first 'p' is highlighted. This looks awkwards.

title: [hovering] Hover labels for local variables
desc: RC2  Hover over a local variable, e.g. x. The hover shows:    'int p.Try2.m().x'  in 3.0 we showed    'int x - p.Try2.m()'  which I think is much better.  As a side note, the important information should be (besides the type of the variable), that this is a local variable or a parameter.   class Try2 {     int m() {         int x = 0;         return x;     } }

title: [preferences] New link on Java Editor pref page does not honor dialog font
desc: I20050615-0010  Omission when fixing bug 99714: the new link on the Java editor preference page does not honor the dialog font.

title: [navigation] NPE while opening the class file editor via hyperlinking

I started at  o.e.jdt.ui.internal.preferences.ImportOrganizePreferencePage, then walked up  the tree of classes it extends.  In PropertyAndPreferencePage, I ctrl+click  PreferencePage, and then I get an error dialog saying 'An internal error  occurred during: "Override indicator installation job".'  The editor view is  blank except for an error message saying "Unable to create this part due to an  internal error.  Reason for the failure: an unexpected exception was thrown."   Details gives the stack trace below.  Exiting Eclipse and restarting let me get one level deeper; then if I continue  walking (this time by ctrl+click on DialogPage), same error happens.  Exiting and restarting yet again let me get all the way in to DialogPage.  And  that's where the inheritance tree ends, and the problem goes away.  And now it won't repro, even if I close all those files, exit, restart, and  repeat the process.  Oh well! title: [content assist] code assist should not touch typed qualified import
desc: In code assist options (Preferences => Java => Editor), it is possible to  select either import or qualified name to be inserted, when eclipse "guesses"  which class is meant. This results, that it's not possible to insert qualified  names with code assist, when needed to emphasize that it is a certain class in  a certain package. (of course, full names can be typed without code assist,  but..)  The proposal is that when typing the qualified name with all of the package  hierarchy, it would be left as typed, even if insert import was selected. At  least I would like to have a check box in the preferences for that...

title: [templates] Use $nl$ in the path to the template translations - TVT 3.1 - TCT 478
desc: Our usage of the templates extension point specifies include files and their translatable properties - we should use $nl$ in the path to the properties file in order to enable translations.

title: [navigation] NPE finding occurences of static initializer
desc: I20050627  Steps:  1) Open the type hierarchy of a source class that has a static initializer.  2) In the lower pane of the Hiearchy tab, rightclick on the static initializer  and pick menu item OccurencesInFile>>Identifier.  See this NPE in the Error  Log:  java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.jdt.ui.actions.FindOccurrencesInFileAction.run (FindOccurrencesInFileAction.java:157) 	at org.eclipse.jdt.ui.actions.SelectionDispatchAction.dispatchRun (SelectionDispatchAction.java:222) 	at org.eclipse.jdt.ui.actions.SelectionDispatchAction.run (SelectionDispatchAction.java:198) 	at org.eclipse.jface.action.Action.runWithEvent(Action.java:996)         ...

title: Class file viewer not updated when corresponding Java file is changed (1GJXXMJ) [editor]
desc: 1. Create a class Test.java 	2. Compile the class (if autobuild is off) 	3. From the Navigator open Test.class 		==> class file editor shows corresponding source 	4. Change Test.java and save it 		==> the class file viewer shows old Java source  	There are two cases here 	1) auto-build is on 		==> class file viewer should show new source 	2) auto-build is off 		==> class file viewer should be cleared and contain something like: 			"Corresponding source has changed but not compiled - the source for the class file can not be displayed" 		Once the Java file is compiled the source should be shown again    NOTES: EG (12.09.2001 15:49:59) 	not convinced that we should show the source at all in this case. Mapping a source file for a class 	file makes sense in the binary JAR scenario but not in the generated class file scenario. 	Proposal, don't show the source for class files in the output folder.

title: [misc] Support BiDi chs in logical expr in java editor
desc: This defect comes from our Hebrew tester. We embed the JDT java editor into another editor, but this defect appears to happen in the plain Java editor in 3.0.x. If it is fixed in 3.1 please let us know.  Here is the text of his report:  --- Enter following definition. Capital letters stand for BiDi chars  	java.lang.String INPUT 	java.lang.String OUTPUT 	 	INPUT = "HELLO"; 	OUTPUT = "WORLD";  	if INPUT != OUTPUT then 		INPUT = "HELLO world";  Result: The actual display will be as follows:  	java.lang.String INPUT 	java.lang.String OUTPUT 	 	HELLO" = INPUT"; 	WORLD" = OUTPUT";  	if OUTPUT =! INPUT then 		HELLO" = INPUT world";   If you type the same text in Eclipse Java Code Editor you  get correct display. ---  We fixed one of the bugs above and got this second report:  --- I still see 	if OUTPUT =! INPUT instead of if INPUT != OUTPUT . In addition please implement some basic function accepting one String and one integer argument abc (String, Int), then call it using Latin and BiDi variable: abc (latin,5); abc (BIDI,4); ---  We determined that this is the behaviour of the JDT editor in 3.0.2.  If you need more information please let me know and we'll try to get it for you.

title: Hyperlinks are still underlined in inactive editor after Ctrl has been released
desc: I20050823-0800 + HEAD of ZRH plugins, including fix for bug 36833  - open a java editor with a hyperlink target - give focus to a view - press and hold Ctrl - hover over a hyperlink target     -> target becomes blue & underlined - release Ctrl - move mouse onto hyperlink target again     -> target still becomes blue & underlined     => expected: target not a hyperlink any more  Minor, since only a visual problem - clicking on such a target does not activate the link.

title: [correction] Quick Fix (Ctrl+1) takes a long time to catch up with current state
desc: The Quick Fix feature (pressing Ctrl+1) takes a very long time to correctly display the list of options. If I  use a new class which is not in the import list the unknown type shows up as an error. Pressing Ctrl+1 to  show a quick fix menu oftens lags behind so that the 'import type' is not shown on the menu. This is  highly annoying ans really slows down workflow. Sometimes it will not update until I do a Save on the file.  Occasionally it refuses to do so until I quit and restart Eclipse.  This happens frequently on a 2.5GHz HP PC with 1GB RAM even with Eclipse given 512MB.  This is symptomatic of a general problem with Eclipse taking a long time before the syntax colouring of  errors and warnings catches up to the current state of the editor.

title: [typing] Smart semicolong option should support anonymizing a class
desc: 1) Place the caret between the closing parenthesis ')' and semicolon ';'. 2) Type an open brace '{'. 3) Type Enter key (carriage return).  See that closing brace '}' is  automatically added, but semicolon ';' is illegally misplaced.  ----------------- Bug.java ------------------------ class Bug {     Object object=new Object(); }

title: [rulers] Double-clicking arrow to open super declaration also enables breakpoint
desc: If I double-click on an arrow-up icon in the ruler (either the blank 'implements' one or the green  'overrides' one), the super declaration is correctly opened and revealed, but also a breakpoint is set in the  just opened super type, usually on a line near the current mouse location.

title: Information about an nls string [refactoring] [editor]
desc: Version: 2.0 Build: 20011219  An string once externalized leaves the coding looking like 	WorkbenchMessages.getString("Save_Resource"), //$NON-NLS-1$ The problem is that when reading the code one has no idea what the string is  (without tracking it down elsewhere).  Is there any way that some flavour of hover assistance could indicate the  string?  Or alternatively have some like F3 open the message catalog file & position me  at the string. This lets me see it & edit it if I want to.  A work around is to include the original string in the comment at the right of  the line but that's too fragile because it will not be up to date as messages  catalogs get edited.

title: Project Specific Code Templates are not persisted across sessions
desc: I tried changing the Code templates for a project. I enabled "Project Specific Settings" and changed the method template. It worked for that session, but if I closed Eclipse and opened it again the settings were restored to Workspace settings.  I would of expected the project specific settings to be stored in the .settings directory of the project so that they can be persisted and sent to CVS.  This is important to us because we do combined open source and commercial development based upon the opensource in the same workspace. The two different types of plugins require different license/copyrights at the head of new java files. We were going to use this capability of project specific template to prevent accidentally having the wrong copyright on the wrong class.

title: [content assist] code assist not correctly exited
desc: R3.1  While reproducing bug 108700 with enabled argument guessing we found out that code assist isn't terminated correctly and linked mode left enabled. The patch attached to bug 108700 fixes this.

title: [content assist] cycling affordance does not update key binding for open editors
desc: 3.2 M2 testing  from bug 110003:  - Go to the keys preference page and configure Ctrl + Shift + Space to 'Specific Content Assist (type: Template proposals)', change the normal Content Assist from Ctrl + Space to somthing else  - in the Java editor type for and press Ctrl + Shift + Space - templates show up   The dialog reads: Press 'Ctrl + Space' for templates  -> Should probably be 'Ctrl + Shift + Space', 'Ctrl + Space' isn't doing anything anymore (as I redefied the setting)

title: [nls tooling] properties editor is RTL in RTL environments
desc: 3.1.1 RC1 with arabic catalogs and -dir rtl  The properties file editor is rtl in a rtl environment which make it unreadable as the keys are not lined up

title: [nls tooling] Configuring accessor class toggles off "Use Eclipse's..." setting
desc: I20051004-0800  On a file that has never been externalized.  Source>Externalize Strings... Toggle on "Use Eclipse's string externalization mechanism" Click Configure... Make changes to accessor class  On return to the externalization wizard, "Use Eclipse's string externalization mechanism" is toggle off.

title: CUEditor won't let me insert just one TAB
desc: Given the following code: 	Pattern pattern = selected 		? new Pattern(null,...) 		: new Pattern(nul,...); <<CARET>>g.setBackgroundPattern(pattern);  I cannot insert a single TAB at the Caret location. typing TAB inserts two TABs. BACKSPACE deletes both.

title: [templates][content assist] Template completion proposal in javadoc inserts a '<' and duplicates last character
desc: I20051025-0800 + ZRH plugins from 20051028_1210 - Select a word in a javadoc comment - press Ctrl+Space => a '<' is inserted (common prefix?) - select the proposal => the template is correctly applied, but the last character of the original selection is (wrongly) added to the end of the inserted proposal

title: [content assist] Inconvenient ranking of template proposal on exact match
desc: I20051031-2000  Steps to reproduce:  /**  * @return null<Ctrl+Space>  */  -> template proposal for "null" template is ranked after link proposal for NPE -> On exact match, templates should be ranked highest in this case

title: [content assist] methods without parameters should never show linked mode
desc: 3.2 M3 test pass  - enable automatic bracket closing - have the CU below - code assist at the caret (|) - insert method()  > expected: there is no linked mode, the caret is behind the closing parenthesis < actual: a linked exit position is set up on the line following the method call.  class X {     void method() {         this.meth|     } }

title: [api] Need a way to get a shared instance of JavaTextTools
desc: JavaTextTools contains tools required to cofigure a java text viewer, and those tools can be shared via JavaTextTools.  Currently, when clients want to use those tools, they need to first create a new instance of JavaTextTools and then share their instance of JavaTextTools in order to share the tools in JavaTextTools.  This seems like it goes against the purpose of JavaTextTools.  You should only really have 1 instance of JavaTextTools (at least per preferenceStore)  Plus, you also need to make sure you dispose JavaTextTools, so by having only 1 instance, it'll be easier to keep track of to dispose.  JDT is already kind of doing this by only creating one instance of JavaTextTools in JavaPlugin.  I think this one instance should be shared amongst other clients  instead of just the jdt plugin.  A new method should be added to JavaUI, getJavaTextTools, which gets JavaTextTools from JavaPlugin.

title: dangerous uses of "new GC(Display)"
desc: a "new GC(Display)" is a very expensive operation on some platforms because it has to create an overlay window for the whole screen to allow for fullscreen drawing.  If the GC is not used for fullscreen drawing but only for getting some FontMetrics, it should be replaced by a "new GC(Shell)" or better by a "new GC(Control)".  See bug #38528 for details.  I've found this occurrence in JDT/UI:  CodeAssistConfigurationBlockInProgress.computeWidth(...)

title: [templates] ClassCastException when using templates in javadoc
desc: Build input for I20060124:  When inserting a template inside javadoc and the "use formatter" option is checked, a ClassCastException is thrown when applying the template.

title: [projection] Missing projection summary when Java 5.0 annotations are used
desc: Build: I20060223-1656  If there is a warning or error in a method, when the method is folded the summarizable annotations are shown on both the vertical and overview rulers.  If the @Override annotation is placed before the method (because it does actual override a method), then when the text is folded the summarizable annotations are not shown in either the vertical or overview rulers.  The projection annotation also moves from being associated with the method, to being associated with @Override (may be co-incidental).

title: [spell checking] Add @category to JavaDocTagDictionary
desc: Title says it all...

title: [projection] Missing Java Code, Missing Lines, Missing Methods
desc: I have downloaded Eclipse 3.2 M5 and M6 and experienced the same issue. I have not experienced this under Eclipse 3.2 M3.  The problem is that when I load some files, this appears to be fairly random, it does not take me to the method that I pick from the outline view. Instead it shows me some code that does not make sense, the line numbers with all the collapsing comments and so fourth expanded STILL has missing lines. For example the line number count will go from 1031 to 1365 and 1373 to 2356 as in the screenshot that I will provide.  I have tried running Eclipse with Java 1.4.2_08 and 1.5.0_06 and both yeilded the same results. I am starting Eclipse with the following command:  C:\eclipse\eclipse.exe -vm C:\jdk1.5.0_06\jre\bin\javaw.exe -debug -consolelog -data C:\cvs_root_opentwins_on_tiopen\Eclipse.Workspace -vmargs -Xmx512M -Xms128M  Obviously this bug makes it extremely difficult to alter code, therefore I have marked it as a blocker. Upon altering the code [by adding a space] and saving it I did not experience any loss of code. It seems to be just an issue whereby it renders the Java code to the screen.

title: indicate overriden methods
desc: Create a visual indicator that signifies that a method in a class overrides a  method from a class it inherits from or impliments.   The visual indicator could include a different color in the outline as well as  a underlined method name in the editor (or something similar, perhaps it could  be configurable).   Right clicking the context menu over an overriden method will give you the  option of opening the editor to the method that is overided.

title: Code assist adds fully qualified type name when import exists
desc: I use code assist to complete the name of a type I want to use. I have turned off the 'Add import instead of qualified name' and use key combination to add the import when I see the fully qualified name for the first time. In 3.1 using code assist for the second time after adding import inserted the name without package information, 3.2.RC1 inserts the fully qualified name. Example follows:  Starting from:  import java.util.Iterator;  public class TestAutoComplete {   public static void main(String[] args) {     ite|           <Ctrl+Space, Enter to select first choice in popup>   } }  Results in:  import java.util.Iterator;  public class TestAutoComplete {   public static void main(String[] args) {     java.util.Iterator|   } }  Expected behaviour:  import java.util.Iterator;  public class TestAutoComplete {   public static void main(String[] args) {     Iterator|   } }   It seems to be a little messy situation because OTOH I saw reports like this: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=101623 So it would be good to know which is the preferred behaviour for this situation.  Regards Mike Grigorov

title: [implementation] Remove workaround for bug 137091
desc: R3.2 RC4  We added a workaround for bug 137091 which can be removed since bug 137091 got fixed for RC5.

title: Cannot completely disable generation of comments
desc: I would like to completely disable comment generation, and believed I had done from the UI, but still, when I type /* and hit return, I get the following:  /*  * This comment is specified in template 'typecomment'. (Window>Preferences>Java>Templates) */  Not only is the comment incorrect, as the correct path is Window>Preferences>Java>Editor>Templates, but I have selected Disable All from the aforementioned path, yet the comment still appears.

desc: I20060519-1206  1. Start with a fresh workspace 2. title: [preferences][content assist] Enhance code assist by allowing more character triggers
desc: I have developed a minimal plugin that I use to great effect to maximize the use of code assist. The plugin merely sets the property for the auto-activation triggers to a long string (chars A-Z and a-z, as well as '.') in order to make all alpha keys plus the '.' triggers.  The feature request, then, is trivial: please increase the limit on auto-activation triggers to 53 (26 + 26 + 1), or greater, to allow people to configure this functionality. I have been using it for over a year and really love it.  I'm attaching the plugin if people would like to try it out. Once the plugin is in, type Ctrl-Alt-Shift-Z to have it set the auto-activation property. The plugin is called "HyperAssist" (org.popejoy.hyperassist).  Thanks, Stuart

title: [implementation] The class file editor does not restore the caret location
desc: I20070208-0010.  The class file editor does not restore the caret location.

title: [preferences] Hyperlink modifiers for 'Java Property Key' should be the same in all editors
desc: I20070321-0010  Hyperlink modifiers for 'Java Property Key' should be the same in all editors. Currently, I have to Ctrl+Alt+click to go from Java editor to Properties File editor, but Ctrl+click to go back.  I'd suggest Ctrl+Alt+click in both directions.

title: [navigation] mark occurrences stops working
desc: I20070427-0010  Suddenly mark occurrences stops working.

title: [misc] Disable save actions on 'Save As...'
desc: 20070502  I think 'Save as...' should better save the file as is, and not try run the Save actions  - You might loose your imports if you save to a project that doesn't have all the types on its class path - On Save As you mostly have to give a new name, which doesn't match the type name. That means the file is already in an error state. Invoking clean up doesn't make things better - The feature is called 'Actions on Save'. I think it would be fair to say that 'Save As...' is not 'Save'

title: Copy Qualified Name should not be enabled in Class File Editor without source
desc: I20070502-0010.  1. open '' 2. Edit > Copy Qualified Name ==> should not be enabled and executing it gives a dialog

title: [syntax highlighting] java editor syntax highlight colour for operators
desc: I would like to be able to syntax highlight the operators in the java language separately from the other elements i.e. things like "=","&","*","!", etc.  My motivation for this is partly poor eyesight - I keep not seeing the not  operator ("!") and misreading if statements.

title: [typing] Delete next/previous word does not stop at linked position boundaries
desc: HEAD  Delete next/previous word does not stop at linked position boundaries because JavaEditor.DeleteNextSubWordAction.findNextPosition(int) reimplements JavaEditor.NextSubWordAction.findNextPosition(int).

title: [formatting] Java Formatter corrupts the source code formatting
desc: The following class shows it before and after I used "Source" - "Format" (using Ctrl+Shift+F has the same effect).  The Java codeformatter preferences are set so that spaces are used instead of tabs. The tabs are 4 spaces. Also, "Insert a newline inside an empty block" is checked. In the Java Editor Typing settings I also checked that spaces are used instead of tabs.  The problem shown below is even worse for the real Java source code I am writing: Whole lines of declarations have been folded into one line.   === BEFORE "Source - Format" ===  /*  * Created on Sep 2, 2003  */  public class MyFormatTest {      /**      * Default Constructor       */     public MyFormatTest() {         super();     }      /**      * Main Method      * @param args not used      */     public static void main(String[] args) {     } }  === AFTER "Source - Format" === /*  * Created on Sep 2, 2003  */public class MyFormatTest {/**      * Default Constructor       */public MyFormatTest() {     super(); }/**      * Main Method      * @param args not used      */public static void main(String[] args) { } }

title: Next/Prev Problem buttons should be disabled when no problems?
desc: Using Eclipse 2.0, Build F1 (buildid: 20020521)  on Windows 2000.  This is rather trivial, but..  When a java editor opens there are 2 new buttons visible at the right end of  the main toolbar (Next Problem, Previous Problem). These buttons are always  enabled, even when there are no problems. When there are no problems clicking  them does nothing. Why not simply disable them when there are no problems?

title: [formatting] "Enable formatting of Javadoc..." causes format to remove space before class javadoc
desc: After enabling "Enable formatting of Javadoc..." in the "Work in Progress" settings under "Java" in the preferences dialog, I formatted a class. The formatter removed the single-line space between the last import statement and the top of my class's Javadoc. Putting the space back and reformatting caused the same result. Turning off "Enable formatting of Javadoc...", putting the space back, and reformatting left it intact.  It should leave the space there.

title: [formatting] Still problems with javadoc formatting (I20030917)
desc:
There are still some problems with with formatting of javadoc in I20030917: - empty lines are removed -- this is not (necessarily) good for readability -- you might even add

automatically here (a new option?) - format code snippets adds additional "*" -- see test output in options dialog - function of "Indent Javadoc tag descriptions not obvious - the following is indented wrong, I believe, /** * Removes this CQLPane. */ public void remove() { } as it becomes /** * Removes this CQLPane. */ public void remove() { } This seems to happen every time the last line isn't a @tag line. The rest really is enhencements: - new option to put

on same line as following paragraph. See example below. - new option to add empty lines around

    and
  • lines. See example below. - the default comment for inherited methods should be left unaltered /* (non-Javadoc) * @see com.nettest.mq.util.CollectionChangeListener#collectionChanged (com.nettest.mq.util.CollectionChangeEvent) */ /** * This class is a simple encapsulation of the different * models needed to construct the header grid. * *

    The header grid has the following characteristics: * *

      * *
    • It has two levels: one for the hierarchy level and one for the attribute. * *
    • It allows for resizing and draging of the headers * *
    • It allows for editing of the header names (with direct consequence on * the hierarchy levels and attributes). * *
    • It uses icons for the attributes to show the type, any sorting and any filtering. * *
    • * *
    * *

    Note that the class does not enherit from {@link com.eliad.swing.extend.JAdvancedGridHeader} * because this later class is final. */ Other than that, no comments... :-)

title: [syntax highlighting] Syntax coloring of comment is lost when replacing text
desc: 3.3 M7  When I replace the complete class comment with itself, the syntax highlighting is lost. This happens only when the comment starts at column 1.  E.g.  package foo.bar;  /** class comment */ class FooBar {}  1. Select the class comment (start at /**, end before or at */) 2. Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V  3. The comment lost its color.
